title: Question 1
content:
The diagram below shows a car of mass $m$ descending a slope. The car, initially at rest, covers a distance of 27 m in 3.0 s.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/5b5634a7-bfb0-4c45-859f-2684b781580b/images/3d546597-f800-49ad-b760-e4ace00a2c04/PH0123.png)


The magnitude of the acceleration is given by


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 3.0 m s$^{-2}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 6.0 m s$^{-2}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 9.0 m s$^{-2}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 81 m s$^{-2}$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
From the equation of motion


- $ s = ut + \dfrac{1}{2} at^2$

initially the velocity, $u$ is zero giving


- $a = \dfrac{\textrm{2 s}}{t^2} \hspace{1em}$

Substituting $t = 3$ s:


- $a=\dfrac{\textrm{(2)(27.0 m)}}{(3.0\ \ce{s})^2} = 6.0$ m s$^{-2}$

title: Question 3
content:
A ball rolls horizontally off the edge of the top of a cliff. It hits the ground at a distance 2.0 m horizontally away from the base of the cliff with a vertical speed of 20 m s$^{-1}$. What is the height of the cliff?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 20 m
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 40 m
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 60 m
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 80 m
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Only the vertical motion needs to be considered here.


- $v^2=u^2+2as$

There is initially no vertical velocity so $u=0$


- $v^2=2gs$
- $20^2 = (2)(10)(s)$
- $s = \dfrac{400}{(2)(10)}$
- $s = 20$ m

Note that for multiple choice questions it is normally appropriate to use 10 m s$^{-2}$ as the acceleration of freefall.

title: Question 6
content:
A coin is tossed vertically upwards from an original height of $1.5$ m above the ground. What is the maximum height reached above the ground if the coin was projected with an initial velocity of 3.0 m s$^{-1}$?  (Take $g=10$ m s$^{-2}$)


- A. $\hspace{1em} 0.45$ m
- B. $\hspace{1em} 1.50$ m
- C. $\hspace{1em} 1.95$ m
- D. $\hspace{1em} 6.00$ m
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Solution 1: 
Maximum height occurs when the final speed $v$ is zero. The height reached above hand


- $\begin{aligned}
  \ s &= \dfrac{v^2 - u^2}{2a}\\
  \ s&=\dfrac{0-9}{-20} \\
  \ &= 0.45\textrm{ m}\\
  \end{aligned}$

To find maximum height above the ground, $0.45$ m $+\ 1.5$ m = 1.95 m

Solution 2: 
Using conservation of energy, kinetic energy is converted completely into gravitational potential energy at the top of the motion


- $\dfrac{1}{2} mv^2 = mgh$
- $\dfrac{1}{2} (3)^2 = 10h$
- $h=0.45$ m

To find maximum height above the ground, $0.45$ m $+\ 1.5$ m = 1.95 m

title: Question 8
content:
The diagram shows the path of a football kicked from the ground.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/77913ebb-9bae-4e51-930d-46be726c3b93/images/38a80183-388d-4a4e-ba55-7b1ef3d0ed2c/Screenshot%202025-03-24%20at%205.29.42%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


Air resistance is negligible. Which of the arrows $A$, $B$, $C$, or $D$ represent the direction of the acceleration of the ball at the instant in time shown?
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
In the absence of air resistance, gravity is the only force acting on the object so its acceleration acts downwards towards the centre of the Earth.
The vertical velocity of the ball is decreasing whilst its horizontal velocity remains the same.

title: Question 10
content:
The graph shows the variation of velocity $v$ with time $t$ of a car.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9458b204-64a8-4fd2-a4e3-610338c08910/images/755ea518-7317-4796-9011-b76e19865247/Screenshot%202025-04-07%20at%208.41.51%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


Consider the following quantities:


- I.DisplacementII.AccelerationIII.Change in velocity

Assuming there were numerical values on the axes, which of the following could be deduced from the graph?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ I only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ II only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Change in velocity can be read from the vertical axis.
The area under the line gives the displacement.
Acceleration can be deduced from the gradient of the graph.
Therefore, all statements are correct and the answer is D.

title: Question 14
content:
A car moves clockwise in a circular path as shown. The direction of its instantaneous velocity at two different times is shown in the diagram.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d69f696e-7bca-4638-956c-90ddd79961d8/images/21aa0775-c02f-42e9-9634-13951995f288/PH0496.png)


Which of the following vectors shows the direction of the change in velocity?
A.$\hspace{3cm}$B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d69f696e-7bca-4638-956c-90ddd79961d8/images/88b7624f-0886-4115-8256-99af940a2b46/PH0496A.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d69f696e-7bca-4638-956c-90ddd79961d8/images/85315f05-4867-40f4-be2d-ccc71a187238/PH0496B.png)

C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d69f696e-7bca-4638-956c-90ddd79961d8/images/7fa46ed6-98b1-4454-aee3-ef279b9768b9/PH0496C.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d69f696e-7bca-4638-956c-90ddd79961d8/images/675b5d83-2283-4319-be39-7fd0e6705a2d/PH0496D.png)
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The change in velocity = final velocity - initial velocity = $v_2 + (-v_1)$. In a vector diagram, we represent $-v_1$ as in the opposite direction to the $v_1$ direction, and then add the vectors $v_2$ and  $(-v_1)$ as shown below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d69f696e-7bca-4638-956c-90ddd79961d8/images/d52701ff-7d73-457d-a85d-d5d2fb5dd7fe/PH0496-1.png)

title: Question 15
content:
The graph below shows how the acceleration of an object $a$ varies with time $t$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ac6b76d-2709-453b-9a01-dd8e09fc7d9c/images/225978ea-87fb-406a-9dc7-0b898236dcf3/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.16.39%E2%80%AFPM.png)


What is the change in speed of the object?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $7.0$ m s$^{-1}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $28.0$ m s$^{-1}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $42.0$ m s$^{-1}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $56.0$ m s$^{-1}$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Change in speed is the magnitude of the area under an acceleration-time graph.
To find the area under the graph we can split it into two sections.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ac6b76d-2709-453b-9a01-dd8e09fc7d9c/images/7a3ccd6a-bb00-4cc1-bb74-81d58abd51b8/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.17.41%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Section 1 is a rectangle. Area $=(4)(7)=28$ m s$^{-1}$
Section 2 is a triangle. Area $= \dfrac{1}{2}(4)(7)=14$ m s$^{-1}$
Total area $= 28+14=42$ m s$^{-1}$
$\underline{\textrm{Alternative solution}}$
This can also be done in one step using the area of a trapezium $A=\dfrac{1}{2}(8+4)(7)=42$ m s$^{-1}$

title: Question 16
content: - Define distance. [1] - An object moves in a straight line on a level road. The variation of the object's distance d with time t is shown on the graph below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ad709bc-247a-45b1-a942-664f5d258dce/images/ec0aad4a-2afd-42a6-8ebe-1a8af181242f/Screenshot%202025-07-02%20at%202.47.38%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG) - Describe the motion of the object between $t=0.5$ s and $t=1.0$ s. [1] - Calculate the instantaneous speed of the object at $t=0.5$ s. [2] - On the axes below, sketch a possible graph of the variation of velocity $v$ of the object with time $t$. There is no need to add values to the axes. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ad709bc-247a-45b1-a942-664f5d258dce/images/c787d9d0-d867-4d03-980d-27f4c5fbad95/Screenshot%202025-07-02%20at%202.50.32%E2%80%AFPM.png) - Determine the direction of the change in momentum of the object during the motion. [2]
markScheme:
- Length of the path followed $\checkmark$
  
- 
  - Slows down/decelerates $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The slope of the graph gives the speed of the object. The slope decreases between $t=0.5$ s and  $t=1.0$ s. Therefore the object slows down.
    
  - Any evidence for drawing tangent at $t=0.5\, s$ $\checkmark$
    $\ll\dfrac{28-10}{1-0}=\gg18\pm2\, m\,s^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The gradient of the graph at the time of interest gives the instantaneous speed of the object. To find the gradient, the tangent line should be drawn.
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ad709bc-247a-45b1-a942-664f5d258dce/images/db214a2c-2e68-4bce-8a9a-e0cd2cc8719c/Screenshoot%202025-07-02%20at%202.52.52%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


    The gradient of the tangent line =$\dfrac{28-10}{1-0}=18$ m s$^{-1}$
    
  - A straight or a curved line with a negative gradient $\checkmark$
    Starts from the y-intercept and ends up at the x-axis $\checkmark$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2ad709bc-247a-45b1-a942-664f5d258dce/images/4ba5e265-a440-45f1-81d9-62bf89b670e0/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2011.30.12%E2%80%AFAM.png)


    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The gradient of the distance-time graph indicates the speed of the object. In one-dimensional motion, speed and velocity have the same magnitude. Since the gradient gets a smaller value with time and ends up with a zero value, velocity gets smaller and be zero at the end.
    The exact mathematical shape of the distance-time curve is not known, therefore it is not possible to determine the exact shape of the velocity-time graph. A linear graph has been included here, but curvature in the graph is permitted.
    
  - The final momentum is less than the initial momentum $\checkmark$
    Opposite to the motion/backwards/negative $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The velocity of the object decreases. Therefore, the final momentum $p_f$ is less than the initial $p_i$ momentum. The change in momentum $\Delta p$;
    
    
    - $\Delta p=p_f-p_i$

    since $p_i$ > $p_f$, the result should be negative which indicates the direction of the change in momentum is opposite to the motion of the object.

title: Question 18
content:
A football player kicks a ball initially at rest. The ball reaches a speed of 36 km h$^{-1}$ in a time of 0.5 s. Which of the following is the acceleration of the ball in terms of the gravitational acceleration, $g$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 0.2$g$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 0.5$g$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 2$g$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 7$g$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Converting 36 km h$^{-1}$ to m s$^{-1}$:


- 36 km h$^{-1}=\dfrac{36000\ \ce{m}}{3600\ \ce{s}} = 10\ \ce{ m s}^{-1}$

Acceleration is $\dfrac{\textrm{change\ in\ velocity}}{\textrm{change\ in\ time}}$
therefore


- $a=\dfrac{10}{0.5} = 20$  m s$^{-2}$

Approximating $g$ to be 10 m s$^{-2}$, the correct answer is  $2g$.

title: Question 30
content:
A ball is released from rest at a height $h$ above the ground. At each bounce 75% of its kinetic energy is lost. Which graph represents the variation of the ball's velocity $v$ with time $t$ from the beginning of motion until the moment just before the third bounce? Assume the acceleration of the ball is in in the negative direction and that air resistance is negligible.

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/396ed74a-f81b-44b3-b9ab-6a05c85de26b/images/a516a5f2-3a03-4885-811d-0da67b6ad48e/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.31.14%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/396ed74a-f81b-44b3-b9ab-6a05c85de26b/images/c52e4b88-650f-407b-aa7e-ecf2ab94b5f1/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.31.26%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/396ed74a-f81b-44b3-b9ab-6a05c85de26b/images/f9d6effd-a838-49ed-b769-1e65f233ace2/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.31.34%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/396ed74a-f81b-44b3-b9ab-6a05c85de26b/images/75cb8fb0-e10e-4e0e-b129-422f1813f50d/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.31.41%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Kinetic energy $E_k$ is directly proportional to the square of the magnitude of velocity $v$


- $E_k = \dfrac{1}{2} mv^2$

The velocity will decrease to half of its value at each bounce.
The value of the acceleration is constant, free fall acceleration $g$. The velocity time graph should be linear and all sections should have a negative gradient to represent downwards acceleration.
The direction of velocity is positive on the way up, and negative on the way down.

title: Question 31
content:
A ball is released from rest and falls vertically for 3 s on Earth. Air resistance is negligible. What is the average speed of the ball during the motion?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 3 m s$^{-1}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 10 m s$^{-1}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 15 m s$^{-1}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 30 m s$^{-1}$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Solution 1:


- $v = u + at = 0 + (10)(3) = 30$ m s$^{-1}$
- $v_{av} = \dfrac{v+u}{2} = \dfrac{30+0}{2} = 15$ m s$^{-1}$


Solution 2: 
Distance covered by the ball;


- $s = \dfrac{1}{2} at^2$

Due to absence of air resistance;


- $a = g$
- $s = \bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg)(10)(3)^2$
- $s = 45$ m

$\textrm{average speed} = \dfrac{\textrm{total distance}}{\textrm{total\ time}}$
$\textrm{average speed} = \dfrac{45}{3} = 15$ m s$^{-1}$

title: Question 34
content:
A projectile is launched horizontally on Earth with initial speed of $3.0$ m s$^{-1}$ from a height of $5.0$ m above the ground.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/adca8fcd-c774-446b-a421-eb944e4ddd54/images/51e584df-f2d9-4096-bc80-662140961015/PH0851aaaa.png)


What is the magnitude of the displacement of the stone when it reaches the ground?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $5.0$ m
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $8.0$ m
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sqrt{34}$ m
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sqrt{51}$ m
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
For the time, analyzing the vertical direction
$\hspace{1em}$ $s = \dfrac{1}{2}at^2$
$\hspace{1em}$ $5 = \dfrac{1}{2}(10)t^2$
$\hspace{1em}$ $t = 1$ s
The horizonal displacement is
$\hspace{1em}$ $\Delta x = u_x t = (3)(1) = 3$ m
The vertical displacement from the diagram is $5$ m.
The net displacement is


- Displacement $=\sqrt{5^2 + 3^2} = \sqrt{34}$ m

title: Question 35
content: In an experiment, the free-fall of a ball bearing is used to measure the acceleration due to gravity. The ball bearing is suspended with an electromagnet. Then it is released from a height of $h$ above a table. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b6848fbc-0481-4c9b-b67f-b3f36ef6cef1/images/b0277bbd-a6fc-4971-907d-53ec8cd7191f/PH0511_A.png) $\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Created with chemix - https:// chemix.org/]}}$ The time t needed for the ball bearing to reach the ground after release is measured. The experiment is repeated for different values of $h$. The theoretically predicted relationship between time t and h is $t^2=\dfrac{2h}{g}$ - State why there is a need to collect data for a range of values of $h$ to verify this relationship. [1] - The experimental data for $t^2$ and h are plotted on the graph below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b6848fbc-0481-4c9b-b67f-b3f36ef6cef1/images/be791221-65d1-438f-8aba-c562a49fd9e8/Screenshot%202025-04-16%20at%209.01.00%E2%80%AFAM.png) - Draw the line of best fit for the plotted data on the graph. [1] - Suggest whether the data is consistent with the theoretical prediction. [2] - By using the line of best fit, determine a value for g and state the units. [4] - The theoretical relationship is for an object falling in a vacuum. - Compare the experimental result to the accepted value of g and suggest a reason for the discrepancy. [2] - State and explain whether the source of error in (c)(i) is a systematic or random error. [2]
markScheme:
- To prove the relationship between $t^2$ and h different values are needed to find a trend
  OR
  to reduce random error $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
To prove a relationship, one piece of data is not enough. The relationship can be generalized by using a graph where multiple points can reveal a trend. More data allows for drawing a graph that can support the relationship. Additionally, using more data and taking the average of them reduces the amount of random error.



- 
  - A straight line with roughly equal numbers of points above and below the line $\checkmark$

  
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b6848fbc-0481-4c9b-b67f-b3f36ef6cef1/images/e907ca39-4906-4c19-acce-6de827b937d7/Screenshot%202025-04-16%20at%209.01.10%E2%80%AFAM.png)


  
  - $\ll$ According to the theory $\gg$  $t^2$ is proportional to $h$ OR ${t^2}\propto\ h$ $\checkmark$
    A best-fit line that is a straight line that passes through the origin can be drawn $\checkmark$
    $\ll$  Yes $\gg$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
According to the predicted relationship;
    
    
    - $t^2\propto h$

    This relationship suggests that the graph should be a straight line which passes through the origin. According to plotted data, that kind of straight line can be drawn.
  - Rearrangement of the formula to solve for $g$
    
    
    - $g=2\dfrac{h}{t^2}$ $\checkmark$

    Using a correct  data point on the line
    OR
    Correct calculation of  the gradient $\checkmark$
    g is between 9.0 and 9.5 $\checkmark$
    $\ce{m s}^{-2}$ $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The given formula is
    
    
    - $t^2=\dfrac{2h}{g}$

    The gradient is therefore equal to $\dfrac{2}{g}$.
    Finding the gradient gives
    
    
    - gradient = $\dfrac{0.19}{0.9}=0.21$

    Solving for $g$:
    
    
    - $0.21 = \dfrac{2}{g}$
    - $g=\dfrac{2}{0.21}=9.5\ \ce{m s}^{-2}$





- 
  - Experimental result is lower $\checkmark$
    There is air resistance which $\ll$ will result in using exaggerated value of time in the equation $\gg$ $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The time t should be smaller than the measured value under the frictionless environment. According to the equation,
    
    
    - $g=2\bigg(\dfrac{h}{t^2}\bigg)$

    Therefore in the absence of air resistance, the experimental value for $\dfrac{h}{t^2}$ would be greater than the values obtained in this experiment. Therefore, the calculated value is lower than the accepted value.
  - Systematic $\checkmark$
    The result of the experiment is always less than the actual value/results are biased in one direction only $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The error is the result of the design of the experiment and leads to the results always being less than the actual value. Therefore, it is systematic.

title: Question 41
content:
A body is moving in a straight line with a constant acceleration of $a$. Its speed increases from $u$ to $v$ in a time of $t$. Consider the following expressions:


- I.$ut+\dfrac{(v-u)t}{2}$ $\hspace{1em}$II.$vt-\dfrac{1}{2} at^2$ $\hspace{1em}$III.$\dfrac{(v-u)t}{2}$

Which expression(s) can be used to determine the displacement of the body during the time interval $t$?



- A. I only
- B. II only
- C. I and II only
- D. II, and III only
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
When the expression in I is simplified, it is equal to;


- $\dfrac{(v+u)t}{2}$

This is a uniform acceleration formula for displacement, where the average velocity is multiplied by the time taken.
This is included in the data booklet as the formula of displacement.
Comparing expression III to expression I, it can be seen that expression III will give a lower value than expression I. Therefore, It does not give displacement.
For expression II:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1eaa9bbe-f2f8-4aec-98be-a12855120b47/images/b5c4fc0d-f50e-49a3-a2c4-636e71ca5341/PH0540.png)


Using the above graph to analyze expression II. The area under the sloping line will give the displacement. The area of this trapezoid can be found by subtracting the area of triangle $vXu$ from the area of rectangle $OvXt$.
The area of $OvXt$ is $vt$.
The area of $vXu$ is $\frac{1}{2}(v-u)t$
We know that $v - u = at$, thereforen after substitution, the area $vXu$ is equal to $\frac{1}{2}at^2$.
Subtracting the two areas gives the expression $vt - \frac{1}{2}at^2$, which is the same as expression II.
Therefore the correct answer is C

title: Question 43
content:
A stone is thrown vertically upward in the presence of air resistance. Which of the following graphs best shows the variation of velocity $v$ of the stone with time $t$ until it reaches the maximum height above the ground?
A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/07795333-081c-45d6-a535-7d81fe684558/images/1372cf34-9ff4-41eb-8e1b-409b309a48d5/PH0533aa.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/07795333-081c-45d6-a535-7d81fe684558/images/7a0b7787-0fec-4f49-8e31-29ea318dae6d/PH0533bb.png)

$\hspace{1em}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/07795333-081c-45d6-a535-7d81fe684558/images/42a7ebb7-983c-4564-8c3c-7e51b7981ded/PH0533cc.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/07795333-081c-45d6-a535-7d81fe684558/images/f92baaf5-5218-4036-bc1c-47f423955d9d/PH0533dd.png)
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
While the stone is ascending, its speed decreases due to gravitational attraction and air resistance. Although gravitational attraction is constant, air resistance decreases with speed. Therefore, the total force opposing the motion decreases. This results in a decrease in deceleration.
When the acceleration decreases, the change in velocity gets lower for a constant change in time. Thus the gradient should decrease. Additionally, the velocity of the stone must be zero when it reaches maximum height. These two conditions are satisfied in choice C.

title: Question 1
content:
The diagram below shows a tennis ball of mass $m$ striking a wall with an initial velocity, $u$, and rebounding with velocity $v$. A second, softer ball of the same mass strikes the wall with the same speed but rebounds with a slower rebound speed.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4bbeffe1-fadb-4f69-a8f6-5a1deb1f20d3/images/a440cac5-43c9-4b14-97ec-4b768f633978/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.33.06%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Which of the following statements is correct about the magnitudes of the impulse and change in momentum applied to the second ball compared to the first?

$\hspace{1em}$  Impulse$\hspace{1em}$Change in momentum$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$GreaterSmaller$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$SmallerGreater$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$GreaterGreater$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$SmallerSmaller
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The change in momentum and impulse applied to the ball are equal, because the impulse is defined as the change in momentum. Increasing one is the same as increasing the other and vice-versa. The slower rebound speed of the second ball causes a decrease in the magnitude of the impulse since the change in momentum is smaller if the final speed $v$ is smaller.


- $J = \Delta p = m(v - -u) = m(v + u)$

title: Question 8
content:
The graph below shows the variation of the resultant force $F$ acting on a box with time $t$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4aa12405-aa9a-459e-a7d1-0f7fb93cfd4d/images/9dfa696e-4fd4-4a7a-90d1-8830c669456a/PH0579q.png)


The box starts to move from rest. Which of the following graphs shows the variation of the momentum $p$ of the box with time $t$?
A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4aa12405-aa9a-459e-a7d1-0f7fb93cfd4d/images/71fb8624-3e7f-4803-b78f-8670d2c4c075/PH0579a.png)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4aa12405-aa9a-459e-a7d1-0f7fb93cfd4d/images/5df1dc95-d879-42fa-9bf5-f4a182c14b3f/PH0579b.png)

$\hspace{1em}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4aa12405-aa9a-459e-a7d1-0f7fb93cfd4d/images/10ae312c-2976-4a62-98e5-18a7efeb0dc4/PH0579c.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4aa12405-aa9a-459e-a7d1-0f7fb93cfd4d/images/9fb48b7f-abee-43b9-9d28-76767fb4650b/PH0579d.png)
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The area underneath of the force-time graph gives the change in momentum of the box. Since the area increases with time at a constant rate, the momentum should increase at a constant rate. The only graph that satisfies this condition is the graph in A.
Therefore, the answer is A.
Alternatively, the impulse equation gives $\Delta p = F \Delta t$ .
As $F$ is a constant,  $\Delta p$ is directly proportional to $t$ and a straight line through the origin is expected.

title: Question 9
content:
As a truck is brought to rest, the brakes apply a force of $5.1 \times 10^3$ N. Which answer best describes the magnitude of the change in momentum of the truck if the brakes are applied for 3.0 s?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $15$ kN s
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $15000$ N s
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $15.3$ kN s
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $15300$ N s
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
NOTE this question requires students to use their judgement to determine the best answer, using standard scientific conventions.


- Impulse = change in momentum =
$F \,t $

So the magnitude of the change in momentum:


- $\Delta p= (5.1 \times 10^3$)(3.0) = 15300 N s

All responses match this quantity but the number of significant figures needs to be considered. As both of the values used in the calculation have two significant figures, there should be two significant figures in the answer.
In the answer $15000$ N s, the number of significant figures is unclear. It could be 2, 3, 4 or 5. The response $15$ kN s clearly has two significant figures, so it is the best answer.

title: Question 11
content:
A block of wood is placed on a rough inclined surface. Which of the diagrams below correctly represents the forces acting on the block when it is at rest?

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7eecdfde-2269-4e07-9298-f4a45be13e55/images/6fd66c35-5858-47b6-b951-7ef859c5bc49/PH0261A.png)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7eecdfde-2269-4e07-9298-f4a45be13e55/images/1efb7d4e-b506-4e9a-b16f-c5b29f42f15e/PH0261B.png)

$\hspace{1cm}$ $\hspace{1cm}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7eecdfde-2269-4e07-9298-f4a45be13e55/images/d118c599-94cf-4412-bd58-11ec3f440b08/PH0261C.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/7eecdfde-2269-4e07-9298-f4a45be13e55/images/371d44f4-7847-4a00-acd9-301f34fdd9b2/PH0261D.png)
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Weight always acts vertically downwards
Normal reaction force is always normal (perpendicular) to the surface
In order to remain at rest, friction must act up the incline in order to keep the block from sliding down the incline under the action of the component of weight acting down the incline.
In diagram B, friction is acting down the incline. This will result in an acceleration down the incline.
In diagram C, the normal reaction is acting opposite to the weight whereas normal reaction must always be perpendicular to the contact surface.
In diagram D, weight is shown to act at an angle to the vertical, whereas weight always acts vertically downwards.

title: Question 12
content:
A spring of negligible mass and length of $l_o$ is attached to a fixed point. When the spring is extended by an external force $F$, the length of the spring increases to $l$.  The graph shows how the length of the spring $L$ varies with the tension $T$ in the spring. The tension in the spring is equal to $k \Delta l$, where k is a constant and $\Delta l$ is the extension of the spring.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2bfce454-555d-4156-93d8-281993a72810/images/edd72a10-fd02-4b98-92fe-bdc00c06f9eb/Screenshot%202025-04-03%20at%202.57.48%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


What are the gradient and y-intercept of the graph?

$\hspace{1.5em}$ Gradient $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ y-intercept $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ A. $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{1}{k}$ $l$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ B. $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{1}{k}$ $l_o$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ C. $\hspace{1.5em}$ $k$ $l_o$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ D. $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{1}{k}$ $\Delta l$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The y-intercept is the length of the spring when there is no external force. Therefore, the y-intercept is $l_o$
Gradient is $\cfrac{\Delta y}{\Delta x}$ on the graph
Hooke's Law states that $F = k\Delta x$ and in this case $\Delta x = l - l_o$
The gradient = $\cfrac{l-l_o}{F} = \cfrac{\Delta x}{F}$
Therefore, $gradient = \dfrac{1}{k}$

title: Question 13
content:
A ball of mass $m$ is falling vertically through the air. The drag force acting on the ball is given by $kv^2$ where $k$ is constant and $v$ is the speed of the ball. What is the maximum speed reached by the ball?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{k}{mg}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{mg}{k}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	\sqrt{\dfrac{k}{mg}}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  \sqrt{\dfrac{mg}{k}}$
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
While the ball is falling, two opposite forces act on it. These are weight and drag. The speed of the ball increases until the drag force balances the weight. Therefore, the following expression can be written for maximum speed $v_{max}$:


- $k(v_{max})^2=mg$
- $(v_{max})^2=\dfrac{mg}{k}$
- $v_{max}=\sqrt{\dfrac{mg}{k}}$

Hence, the correct answer is D.

title: Question 20
content:
The diagram below shows the total upward and downward forces acting on a hot air balloon. The relative magnitudes of the forces are drawn to scale.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/df4cb97a-03e0-4bd8-a84c-8dda7444c026/images/3942c2b5-5966-4703-a368-fe8f703caa1a/PH0968Edit.png)


Below are three independent statements about the possible motion of the balloon.


- I.The balloon is acceleratingII.The balloon is moving upwardsIII.The balloon is moving downwards

Which of the statements, when considered independently, could be true?



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ I and II only
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ I and III only
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ II and III only
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ I, II and III
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
I is correct - The diagram shows that the upward force is greater than the downward force. So, there is a net upward force acting on the balloon. $F=ma$ so there is an upward acceleration.
II could be correct – Balloon could be moving upwards - acceleration is also upwards so speed of the balloon would be increasing.
III could be correct – Balloon could be moving downwards - acceleration is upwards so speed of the balloon would be decreasing (deceleration).
For linear motion, acceleration tells us nothing about the speed, just how the speed is changing. The balloon could be moving upwards, moving downwards or stationary.

title: Question 21
content:
A car is travelling along a straight line for a total time of 100 s. Throughout this time the driving force provided by the car is 1.2 kN and the total resistive force acting on the car is 500 N.
Which row correctly shows the rate of change of momentum and the impulse of the car during the 100 s.

Rate of change of momentumImpulse$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$7 $\times 10{^2}$ kg m s${^{-2}}$7 $\times 10{^0}$ kg m s${^{-1}}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$7 $\times 10{^2}$ kg m s${^{-2}}$7 $\times 10{^4}$ kg m s${^{-1}}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$1.7 $\times 10{^3}$ kg m s${^{-2}}$1.7 $\times 10{^1}$ kg m s${^{-1}}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$1.7 $\times 10{^3}$ kg m s${^{-2}}$1.7 $\times 10{^5}$ kg m s${^{-1}}$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Newton's second law states that net force = rate of change of momentum.
Therefore, the rate of change of momentum is simply the net force acting on the car


- $\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=1200$ N - 500 N = 700 N = 700 kg m s$^{-2}=7 \times 10^2$ kg m s$^{-2}$

Impulse


- $J$ = $F_{net}\Delta t$ = (700)(100) = 7 $\times$ $10{^4}$ kg m s$^{-1}$

title: Question 23
content:
An object of mass 3 kg is traveling at velocity of +10 m s$^{-1}$  horizontally. The object explodes into two fragments of mass 1 kg and 2 kg. After explosion, the 1 kg fragment has a horizontal velocity of +30 m s$^{-1}$ and a vertical velocity +20 m s$^{-1}$. This is illustrated below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/726d8f7f-c38d-4f90-846a-264dc5f9390d/images/74ebdb9c-e95a-4274-b0e1-cfcf6b470874/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.20.48%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Which of the following correctly shows the horizontal and vertical components of the momentum of the 2 kg fragment after the explosion?
Assume no external forces act on the object.

Horizontal momentum / $\textrm{kg m s}^{-1}$Vertical momentum / $\textrm{kg m s}^{-1}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $-30$ $-10$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $-30$ $-20$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$0$-10$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$0$-20$
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Momentum is conserved in an isolated system so here momentum before collision = momentum after collision.
Horizontal and vertical directions are independent, momentum is conserved in both.
$\textbf{In the horizontal direction}$:
Initial momentum $= mv=(3)(10)=30$ kg m s$^{-1}$
Final momentum $= 30 =(1)(30)+$ horizontal momentum of 2 kg fragment
Horizontal momentum of 2 kg fragment $=0$
$\textbf{In the vertical direction}$:
Initial momentum $=0$
Final momentum $= 0 =(1)(20)+$ horizontal momentum of 2 kg fragment
Horizontal momentum of 2 kg fragment = $-20$ kg m s$^{-1}$

title: Question 26
content:
A box is sliding down an incline at a constant speed of $2$ m s$^{-1}$. The angle of the incline is $\theta$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/18595241-7849-4c02-a19c-712cdb369317/images/bbdade18-80b2-4de8-9c03-a0393cd56ca3/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.28.45%E2%80%AFPM.png)


The magnitude of the total of the opposing forces is $16$ N. What is the force of gravity acting on the box?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{8}{\sin\theta}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{16}{\sin\theta}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{8}{\cos\theta}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{16}{\cos\theta}$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The box is moving at a constant speed. According to Newton’s First Law, the resultant force acting on the box must be zero. The free body diagram of the forces acting on the box:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/18595241-7849-4c02-a19c-712cdb369317/images/fb785bfc-58f2-4616-b01f-1014614efe2a/PH0547-1.png)


Weight ($F_g$) has two components (shown in red): perpendicular to the slope and parallel to the slope. From the diagram:


- $F_g\cos\theta=F_N \hspace{2em}$ and $\hspace{2em}F_g\sin\theta=16$

Therefore


- $F_g=\dfrac{16}{\sin\theta}$

title: Question 29
content:
A table tennis ball of mass $m$ is dropped on a level surface from a height $H$. The ball rebounds to a height $h < H$ after impact. Air resistance on the ball is negligible. Which of the following is correct about the nature of the collision and magnitude of the change in momentum ($\Delta p$) of the ball as a result of this impact?

Nature of the collisionChange in momentum $\Delta p$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$Elastic$m(\sqrt{2gH}-\sqrt{2gh})$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$Inelastic$m(\sqrt{2gH}-\sqrt{2gh})$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C. $\hspace{1.5em}$Elastic$m(\sqrt{2gH}+\sqrt{2gh})$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D. $\hspace{1.5em}$Inelastic$m(\sqrt{2gH}+\sqrt{2gh})$
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The height of rebound is less than the height of release. This is evidence that some energy is dissipated at the point of impact. Hence inelastic.
We can use conservation of energy to find the velocity upon impact:


- $mgH=\dfrac{1}{2}mu^2$
- $u^2 =2gH$
- $u=\sqrt{2gH} $

Similarly, the velocity just after impact is: $v=-\sqrt{2gh} \hspace{2em}$
Where the negative sign represents the opposite direction to $u$ (upwards)


- $\therefore \Delta p=|mv-mu|$
- $=|m(v-u)|$
- $=m|(-\sqrt{2gh}-\sqrt{2gH})|$

Removing the absolute value gives


- $=m(\sqrt{2gH}+\sqrt{2gh})$

title: Question 33
content:
A car enters a roundabout with a speed $v$. The dotted line shows the path of the car. The road is slightly banked inward at an angle to the horizontal.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/46047306-4c31-4e50-8ee4-a0671285fe55/images/8bef058b-da21-4259-8e52-70155256bcbb/PH0298-1.png)


The coefficient of friction between the tires of the car and the road is $\mu$. When $\mu$ decreases, which of the following changes could prevent the car from slipping away on this roundabout?

$\hspace{1em}$ Banking angle of the turn $\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{3em}$ Speed of the car$\hspace{3em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$increaseincrease$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$decreaseincrease$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$increasedecrease$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$decreasedecrease
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
When $\mu$ decreases, the maximum possible frictional force decreases. Friction acts along with the component of the normal force in the horizontal direction to produce the centripetal force. To account for this change, decreasing the speed will allow the car to require less frictional force due to a lower required centripetal acceleration and safely take the turn.


- $\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=\mu mg$

Increasing the banking angle increases the component of the normal force that points towards the centre of the circle, providing more centripetal force to compensate for the loss in centripetal force contribution from friction. Remember that in this situation friction is acting towards the centre of the circle, and so having an increased component of the normal force acting towards the centre of the circle will $\lq$help' friction to turn the car.

title: Question 37
content: - A ball of mass $0.20$ kg moving on a frictionless horizontal plane collides elastically with a vertical wall. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/53468848-1041-4735-9efe-c31aa4376dbd/images/2895dd52-b8a7-4f2a-8e01-1d5ff5c6a617/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.32.51%E2%80%AFPM.png) The variation of the force $F$ acting on the ball during the collision with time $t$ is shown on the graph below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/53468848-1041-4735-9efe-c31aa4376dbd/images/670df608-825b-4b06-9083-411840c17cbf/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.13.31%E2%80%AFPM.png) The speed of the ball just before the impact is $5.0$ m s$^{-1}$. Calculate the maximum force exerted on the wall by the ball. [3] - The wall is covered with a coating that causes an inelastic collision. The ball hits the wall with the same initial speed and bounces back with a speed of $3.0$ m s$^{-1}$. - Explain, by considering the moments just before and after the collision, how the principle of conservation of energy applies to the collision. [2] - Calculate the loss of the energy of the ball during the collision. [2] - During this collision, the ball undergoes a change in momentum. Discuss whether the the law of conservation of momentum applies in this situation. [2]
markScheme:
- Change in momentum = $\left(0.20\right)\left(5.0\right)-\left(0.20\right)\left(-5.0\right)=2.0$ kg m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
  The area under the graph=change in momentum  $\checkmark$
  $\hspace{2em}$ $F_{max}=\dfrac{(2.0)(2)}{(10\times{10}^{-3})}$ = $400$ N $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The area under the graph gives the change in momentum $\Delta p$;
  $\hspace{2em}$ Area = $\dfrac{F_{max}(10\times{10}^{-3})}{2}=\Delta p$
  $\hspace{2em}$ $\Delta p=mv-mu$
  The ball moves in the opposite direction after the collision
  $\hspace{2em}$ $\Delta p=mv-mu$
  $\hspace{2em}$ $\dfrac{F_{max}(10\times{10}^{-3})}{2}=(0.20)(5.0)-(0.20)(-5.0)$
  $\hspace{2em}$ $\dfrac{F_{max}(10\times{10}^{-3})}{2}=2.0$
  $\hspace{2em}$ $F_{max}=\dfrac{(2.0)(2)}{(10\times{10}^{-3})}=400$ N
  
- 
  - Loss of kinetic energy of the ball $\checkmark$
Equals to the increase in internal energy of the objects and surroundings $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The law of conservation of energy states that in any interaction, energy is not created or destroyed. In this situation, although the ball loses kinetic energy overall, this energy is transferred to thermal energy in the surroundings during the collision.
    
  - $\hspace{2em}$ $E_{Ki}=\dfrac{1}{2}\left(0.2\right)\left(5.0\right)^2=2.5$ J
    and
    $\hspace{2em}$ $E_{Kf}=\dfrac{1}{2}\left(0.2\right)\left(3.0\right)^2=0.9$ J $\checkmark$
    $\hspace{2em}$ $\Delta E_K=2.5-0.9$ = $1.6$ J $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The kinetic energy of the ball $E_{K_i}$ before the collision:
    $\hspace{2em}$ $E_{K_i}=\dfrac{1}{2}\left(0.2\right)\left(5.0\right)^2=2.5$ J
    The kinetic energy of the ball $E_{K_f}$ after the collision:
    $\hspace{2em}$ $E_{K_f}=\dfrac{1}{2}\left(0.2\right)\left(3.0\right)^2=0.9$ J
    The kinetic energy lost $\Delta E_{K}$:
    $\hspace{2em}$ $\Delta E_{K}=2.5-0.9=1.6$ J
    
  - Law states that momentum of a closed system is constant in the absence of external forces. $\checkmark$
    Considering the ball only, the wall exerts an external force therefore its momentum changes.
    OR
    System incorporates the ball and the wall. The change of momentum of the ball is equal and opposite to the change in momentum of the wall/earth $\checkmark$

title: Question 40
content:
A ball of mass 0.5 kg moving horizontally strikes a vertical wall with a speed of 30 m s$^{-1}$. The magnitude of the change of the momentum of the ball is 22.5 kg m s$^{-1}$. Calculate the speed of the ball just after it rebounds.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8425ea05-2617-4ded-b0e9-edb297fa635a/images/d1c76c1d-7e5f-4b4f-b398-e74b073c46a5/PH0247.png)




- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 0 m s$^{-1}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 5 m s$^{-1}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 10 m s$^{-1}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 15 m s$^{-1}$
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Change in momentum;


- $\Delta p = p_f - p_i$

The momentum in the left direction is regarded as negative while the right is positive. Therefore;
$\begin{aligned}
\hspace{0.8
cm}-\Delta p &= -p_f - p_i\\
-\Delta p &= -mv - mu\\
-22.5 &= -0.5v - (0.5)(30)\\
0.5v &= 22.5 - 15\\
0.5v &= 7.5\\
v &= 15\textrm{ m s}^{-1}
\end{aligned}$

title: Question 47
content:
A box with a mass of M rests on a balance in an elevator that is moving downwards. The elevator slows with an acceleration of   $\dfrac{g}{4}$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7dab1f3-5df3-4e27-9cbf-cd571f4fa49c/images/668949a1-7b88-4532-bf3c-3689bdf6f746/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.23.51%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Which of the following gives the reading of the balance?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{5Mg}{4}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	Mg$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{3Mg}{4}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{Mg}{2}$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The reading of the balance is equal to the magnitude of the reaction force. The free-body diagram of the box M:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b7dab1f3-5df3-4e27-9cbf-cd571f4fa49c/images/93aad0fb-70d9-4742-9503-89c79a83c9b5/PH0543-2.png)


Since the elevator slows down downwards, the acceleration must be upwards and the normal reaction force ($F_N)$ must be greater than the weight ($F_g$). According to Newton’s Second Law, the following relationship can be written:


- $F_N - F_g = ma$

When the given expressions are substituted:


- $F_N - Mg=M\bigg(\dfrac{g}{4}\bigg)$
- $F_N = M\bigg(\dfrac{g}{4}\bigg)+Mg$
- $F_N = \dfrac{5Mg}{4}$

Therefore, the answer is A.

title: Question 51
content:
A ball of mass 100 g hits the ground at an angle of $45\degree$ and a speed of 10 m s$^{-1}$. The collision is elastic, and the ball makes contact with the ground for a total time of 100 ms. This is illustrated below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f72f77f-7ad8-483e-b91e-8dfeb4cb15c2/images/99fe19b1-7971-4531-bcfc-196700e2ddb3/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.03.13%E2%80%AFPM.png)


What is the magnitude of the average net force on the ball during the collision?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $7.1$ N
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $10$ N
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $14$ N
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $20$ N
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:


- $F_{net}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{m\Delta v}{\Delta t}$

The horizontal component of the speed/momentum of the object does not change - the force exerted by ground is purely vertical.
Initial and final vertical velocities are $-10\sin{(45\degree)}$ and +$10\sin{(45\degree)}$ if we take upwards as the positive direction (this will give a positive force as the direction of the force exerted by the ground on the ball is upwards) see diagram below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/1f72f77f-7ad8-483e-b91e-8dfeb4cb15c2/images/67e50acf-d004-4a7b-b955-05573f43c304/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.07.40%E2%80%AFPM.png)


For the vertical direction $\Delta v=$ final velocity $-$ initial velocity $=10\sin{45\degree}-(-10\sin{45\degree})=10\sin{45\degree}+10\sin{45\degree}=20\sin{45\degree}$


- $F_{net}=\dfrac{m\Delta v}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{(0.1)(20\sin{45\degree})}{0.1}=20\sin{45\degree}$ = 14 N

(Here we have converted to SI units 100 g = 0.1 kg and 100 ms = 0.1 s)

title: Question 53
content:
An airplane of weight $W$ is flying horizontally with constant velocity. The total forward thrust of the engines is $3W$. Which of the following gives the magnitude of the force of the air on the plane?


- A. $\hspace{1em} 4W$
- B. $\hspace{1em} 3W$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sqrt{10}W$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sqrt{8} W$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Due to the absence of acceleration, the resultant force must be zero. Therefore, both the forward thrust and the weight must be cancelled by forces from the air.
The force from the air has two components; $3\, W$ in backward drag and $W$ in upward lift.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3007ef36-6df7-4d85-8b06-cbef0a761c62/images/4c76b22c-495d-4463-b7dc-a89c63d18c53/Screenshot%202025-07-03%20at%204.59.56%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Using Pythagoras' theorem to find the resultant of these two components:


- R = $\sqrt{(3W)^2+ W^2 } = \sqrt{10}\,  W$

title: Question 54
content: While practising, a table tennis player hits a ball of mass 2.8 g that collides with the floor and then bounces back from the wall. The speed of the ball just before reaching the floor is 8.0 m s$^{-1}$. The ball leaves the floor with an angle of 65$\degree$ to the floor as shown. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3f046049-9d52-4f31-bdb9-04593858342e/images/33f83956-3349-49c0-b000-e177f8854ee9/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.39.45%E2%80%AFPM.png) - Due to the collision with the floor, the ball losses 30$\%$ of its initial kinetic energy. Show that the leaving speed of the ball from the floor is around 7 m s$^{-1}$. [2] - The ball strikes the wall just as it reaches the highest point of its motion. Determine the horizontal distance between the bounce point and the wall. [3] - The ball collides elastically with the wall, with the time of contact during the collision is 0.040 s. Calculate the average horizontal force exerted by the wall on the ball during the collision. [2]
markScheme:
- $\textrm{Initial\ Kinetic\ Energy}=\dfrac{1}{2}(2.8\times{10}^{-3})({8)}^2=0.090$ J $\checkmark$
  
  
  - $v= \sqrt{\dfrac{(0.7)(.090\ )(2)}{(2.8\times{10}^{-3})}}=\answer{6.7\ \ce{m s}^{-1}}$ $\checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
The kinetic energy $E_{ki}$ just before the collision; $E_{ki}=\dfrac{1}{2}mu^2$  where $u$ is the speed of the ball just before the collision
  
  
  - $E_{ki}=\dfrac{1}{2}(2.8\times{10}^{-3})({8)}^2=0.090$ J

  Since 30$\%$ of the $E_{ki}$ is lost, the final kinetic energy $E_{Kf}$ is
  
  
  - $E_{kf}=\left(0.7\right)\left(0.090\right)=0.063$ J
  - $E_{kf}=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2$,  where $v$ is the speed of the ball just after the collision
  - $0.063=\dfrac{1}{2}(2.8\times{10}^{-3})({v)}^2$
  - $v=\sqrt{\dfrac{(0.063)(2)}{(2.8\times{10}^{-3})}}=6.7$ m s$^{-1}$

  
- Vertically,
  
  
  - $u_y = 6.7\sin(65\degree)$ $\checkmark$
  - $t\ =\ \dfrac{v-u}{a}\ =\ \dfrac{0\ -\ 6.7\sin({65\degree})}{9.8}\ = \ 0.62$ s $\checkmark$

  Horizontally,
  
  
  - $s=vt=6.7\cos({65\degree})\left(0.62\right)=\answer{1.8\ \ce{m}} \ \checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
The ball undergoes projectile motion. The collision with the wall takes place when the ball is at the highest part of its motion, so the vertical component of the motion can be used to find the time of flight.
  
  
  - $u_y = 6.7\sin(65\degree)$ and $y = 0$
  - $t\ =\ \dfrac{v-u}{a}\ =\ \dfrac{0-6.7\sin\left({65\degree}\right)}{9.8}\  =\ 0.62$ s

  Using this time in the horizontal direction, where $u_x = 6.7\cos(65\degree)$
  
  
  - $s=vt=6.7\cos\left({65\degree}\right)\left(0.62\right)=1.8$ m




- $\Delta p = 2mv = 2(0.0028)(6.7\cos(65\degree)) =0.016$ N s $\checkmark$
  
  
  - $F\ =\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}= \dfrac{0.016}{0.040}= \answer{0.40\ \ce{N}} \ \checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$:
As the ball rebounds elastically, the final speed is equal to the initial speed.
  These speeds are equal to the horizontal component of the velocity
  
  
  - $v_x=6.7\cos(65\degree) =2.83$ m s$^{-1}$

  To find change in momentum
  $\begin{aligned}
   \Delta p&=p_2-p_1 \\
   &=mv_2-mv_1 \\
   &=0.0028\left(2.83-\left(-2.83\right)\right)
   =0.016\textrm{ N s}
   \end{aligned}$
  Note that because of the change in direction, the change in momentum is equal to twice the initial momentum.
  To find force,
  
  
  
  - $F\ =\ \dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{0.016}{0.040}= 0.40$ N

title: Question 56
content: - - A spacecraft is moving in a zero gravity zone in space with constant speed. Its pilot decided to accelerate by burning fuel. The burned fuel is ejected backwards from the rocket with a constant speed of $2.5\times{10}^2$ m s$^{-1}$ relative to the rocket at a constant rate of $2.0\times{10}^2$ kg s$^{-1}$. Show that the net force on the rocket due to the ejection of burnt fuel is $5 \times 10^4$ N. [1] - The spacecraft has a mass of $4.2\times{10}^3$ kg at the instant that it starts to burn the fuel. Calculate the acceleration of the spacecraft after $1.0$ s has passed. [2] - The spacecraft enters the atmosphere of Mars and slows down due to friction. To decelerate its speed more to reach a safe landing speed, the operator runs a propeller that pushes against the gas in the atmosphere. - By referring to Newton's Third Law, outline why there is a force acting on the spacecraft due to the propeller. [2] - The average density of the Mars atmosphere is $0.020$ kg m$^{-3}$. The radius of the propeller blades is $1.2$ m. At a given instant, the average force from the propeller to slow down the spacecraft is $1.4$ kN. Assuming that the propeller causes all gas that it passes through to come to rest relative to the falling spaceship, estimate the speed of the spaceship at this instant. [4] - The landing legs of the spacecraft have springs that can compress as the spacecraft makes contact with the ground. Explain how this decreases the average force acting on the spacecraft as it lands. [3]
markScheme:
- 
  - $F=\dfrac{\Delta(mv)}{\Delta t} = \dfrac{\Delta m}{\Delta t} v = (2.0\times{10}^2\ \ )(2.5\times{10}^2) = \answer{5.0 \times 10^4}$ << N >>$\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
From Newton's 3rd Law, the force of the rocket on the gases is equal to the force of the gases on the rocket.
    For the gases, the net force is equal to the rate of change of momentum.
    Substituting in the values will lead the net force
    $\begin{aligned}
     F&=\dfrac{\Delta(mv)}{\Delta t}\\
      &= \dfrac{\Delta m}{\Delta t} v \\
      &= (2.0\times{10}^2\ \ )(2.5\times{10}^2) \\
      &= 5.0 \times 10^4\textrm{ N}\\
      \end{aligned}$

  
  
  - Mass of the rocket at $t=1$ s is
    
    
    - $4200-\left(2.0\times{10}^2\right)\left(1.0\right)=4.0\times{10}^3$ kg $\checkmark$
    - $a=\dfrac{F_{net}}{m}=\dfrac{5\times{10}^4}{4.0\times{10}^3} = $ $12.5$ m s$^{-2}$ $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The total mass $m_t$ of the rocket after $1$ s:
    
    
    - $m_t=4200-\left(2.0\times{10}^2\right)\times\left(1.0\right)=4.0\times{10}^3$ kg

    To find the acceleration of the rocket:
    
    
    - $a=\dfrac{F_{net}}{m}=\dfrac{5\times{10}^4}{4.0\times{10}^3}=12.5$ m s$^{-2}$

    

- 
  - Propellor exerts a force on the gas $\checkmark$
    There is an equal and opposite force from the gas on the propeller $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The gas in the atmosphere experiences a force due to the propeller blades. According to Newton's Third Law, a force with the same magnitude and opposite direction acts on the spacecraft.
    
  - $F_{av}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}{} = m\dfrac{\Delta v}{\Delta t}\, \checkmark$
    $m=\rho V=\rho Al=\rho\pi r^2vt \, \checkmark$
    $v=\sqrt{\dfrac{F_{av}}{\rho\pi r^2}}\ \, \checkmark$
    = $120$ m s$^{-1}$ $\, \checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The distance $l$ covered by the spacetime in a short time of $t$:
    $l=vt$   where $v$ is the average speed of the spacecraft
    The mass $m$ of the gas pushed during the time of $t$:
    $m=\rho V=\rho Al=\rho\pi r^2vt$ where $r$ is the radius of the blades
    The mass experiences a change of velocity of $v$, as relative to the aircraft it is initially moving at speed $v$ and comes to rest due to the propellors
    The average force $F_{av}$ needed from the propeller;
    $\begin{aligned}
     F_{av}&=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}\\
     \hspace{1.3cm}\\
     &=\dfrac{m\Delta v}{\Delta t}\\
     \hspace{1.3cm}\\
     &= \dfrac{\rhoπr^2vt\Delta v}{\Delta t}\\
     \hspace{1.3cm}\\
     &=\rhoπr^2v^2\\
     \end{aligned}$
    Rearranging gives
    $\hspace{1.12cm}v=\sqrt{\dfrac{F_{av}}{\rho\pi r^2}}=\sqrt{\dfrac{1.4\times{10}^3}{(0.020)\pi{(1.2)}^2}}=120$ m s$^{-1}$
    
  - $\Delta p=F_{av}\Delta t$   $\, \checkmark$
    duration of the collison is increased $\, \checkmark$
    Change in momentum is the same so the average force is less $\, \checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The time of collision is increased with using soft material.  By using Newton’s second law;
    
    
    - $F_{av}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}$

    For the same magnitude of the change in momentum, the average force acting on the object is less when the time of collision is increased.

title: Question 58
content:
A mass $m$ is moving on a circular path at the end of a rope of constant length. The centripetal force acting on the mass is $F$.
The frequency of the motion is gradually increased.
Which graph correctly shows the change of the centripetal force $F_c$ as the frequency $f$ is increased?

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9355d0bc-b468-46df-9c70-230fb22bb2de/images/775fbf10-3bc4-4ebe-b512-ff6082e1e19e/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.18.18%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9355d0bc-b468-46df-9c70-230fb22bb2de/images/5cdacb61-797f-46e1-8f53-056da57c9dda/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.18.23%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9355d0bc-b468-46df-9c70-230fb22bb2de/images/08449c73-c15e-47dc-ac1c-b31237189261/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.18.28%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9355d0bc-b468-46df-9c70-230fb22bb2de/images/630ba233-a848-4273-b0a6-76a57dfee62b/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2010.18.32%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
In the data booklet, given centripetal acceleration:


- $a=\dfrac{4\pi^2r}{T^2}$

which can also be expressed as


- $a=4\pi^2rf^2$

Since $F=ma$,


- $F=m4\pi^2rf^2$

Therefore the graph of $F$ vs $f$ must be a quadratic as in A.

title: Question 60
content:
During a game of pool, a cue ball traveling at a velocity $v$ collides with a stationary ball. After the collision each of the balls move at 45 degrees to the initial velocity of the cue ball as shown in the diagram.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4e45fdf3-ab76-456e-a437-96f212df97cb/images/173e20c4-e008-4a67-934a-ffae87cc8b5f/Screenshot%202025-02-26%20at%209.21.31%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


The mass of each of the balls is $m$. What is the impulse experienced by either of the balls in the collision?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{mv}{2}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{mv}{\sqrt{2}}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $mv$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sqrt{2}$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Due to symmetry, the final velocities $V$ of the balls will be the same. We can see this as the masses are the same and the magnitude of the vertical components of the velocity must be the same due to conservation of vertical momentum.
Impulse ($J$) is equal to change in momentum. The simplest way to find the impulse of this collision is to consider the change in momentum of the ball that is initially stationary.


- $J=m\Delta v$

We can find the horizontal component of this velocity $V_H$ using conservation of momentum. Setting the horizontal momentum before the collision equal to the horizontal momentum after the collision:


- $mv+0=mV_H+mV_H$
- $mv=2mV_H$
- $V_H=\dfrac{v}{2}$

After the collision, the balls move at 45° (so the vector triangle is isosceles) so the magnitude of the vertical component of the balls' final velocity is equal to the horizontal component


- $V_V=V_H=\dfrac{v}{2}$.

Now $V$ is the vector sum of $V_H$ and $V_V$, which can be calculated using Pythagoras' theorem:


- $V=\sqrt{V_H^2+V_V^2}=\sqrt{\left(\dfrac{v}{2}\right)^2+\left(\dfrac{v}{2}\right)^2}=\sqrt{\dfrac{v^2}{2}}=\dfrac{v}{\sqrt{2}}$

Because the ball was initally stationary, this also represents the change in velocity of the ball. The impulse of the collision is therefore:


- $I=mV=\dfrac{mv}{\sqrt2}$

title: Question 64
content:
A block of mass 4.0 kg rests on an inclined plane.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4498c7b1-1fec-4afe-b22e-1ae34aaaf744/images/a2d8fdc5-6a82-406e-a19b-9649d2967b5c/PH0330.png)


The coefficient of static friction between the block and the plane $\mu _s$ is 0.4.
Which of the following gives the angle of inclination at which the block will start to slide?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sin^{-1}(0.4)$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $\tan^{-1}(0.4)$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\cos^{-1}(0.4)$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\tan^{-1}(0.6)$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4498c7b1-1fec-4afe-b22e-1ae34aaaf744/images/1ea450be-a2a5-44f8-aca9-38d06abc4237/Screenshot%202025-05-27%20at%205.09.47%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)




- $F_N = mg\cos\theta$
- $F = \mu_sF_N$
- $F = mg\sin\theta$
- $mg(\sin\theta) = 0.4mg(\cos\theta$)
- $\dfrac{\sin\theta } {\cos\theta}=0.4$
- $\tan\theta = 0.4$
- $\theta=\tan^{-1}(0.4)$

title: Question 65
content:
Two objects of mass $M$ and $m$ are connected via a frictionless pulley. The rope attached to the object of mass $M$ makes an angle $\theta$ with the horizontal. The objects are at rest.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/4a39026f-aa75-494c-a20c-39635e9e1fc0/images/155ede1a-26a4-4810-8047-d312bfef3356/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.43.54%E2%80%AFPM.png)


For the large mass, which expressions are correct for the force of friction F$_f$  and the normal force F$_N$?

$\hspace{3em}$ F$_f$ $\hspace{3em}$ $\hspace{4em}$ F$_N$ $\hspace{4em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg \cos\theta$ $Mg - mg \sin\theta$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg \sin \theta$ $Mg - mg \sin\theta$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg \sin \theta$ $Mg - mg \cos\theta$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg \cos\theta$ $Mg - mg \cos\theta$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Resolving vertical forces on the large block:


- $F_g = F_N + T\sin \theta$

And for the large block,


- $F_g = Mg$

Substituting and solving for $F_N$ gives


- $F_N =  Mg - T\sin \theta$

Resolving horizontal forces on the large block:


- $F_f = T \cos \theta$

For the vertical forces small block


- $T = mg$

Substituting gives $F_f = mg \cos \theta$

title: Question 68
content:
A toy of mass $m$ is attached to a rod of length $L$ and undergoes circular motion in the vertical plane. The radial force $F$ of the rod is constant.
What is the ratio of the linear speed at the top to the linear speed at the bottom of its path, $\dfrac{v_{top}}{v_{bottom}}$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{F-mg}{F+mg}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{F+mg}{F-mg}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sqrt{\dfrac{F-mg}{F+mg}}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\sqrt{\dfrac{F+mg}{F-mg}}$
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$: 
At the top, the centripetal force is $F+mg=\dfrac{m(v_{top})^2}{r}$
At the bottom, the centripetal force is $F-mg=\dfrac{m(v_{bottom})^2}{r}$
Rearranging the above equations for the required ratio gives:
$\hspace{3em}$ $\dfrac{v_{top}}{v_{bottom}}=\sqrt{\dfrac{F+mg}{F-mg}}$

title: Question 70
content: A car enters a horizontal circular roundabout as shown with a speed of 35 km h$^{-1}$. The radius of the roundabout is 15 m. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ae5d5d2c-d886-4aa8-875e-97c202da73d1/images/678c565e-beaf-419e-8ae6-5608f15c2ecf/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%201.32.11%E2%80%AFPM.png) - State the force which provides the centripetal force for the circular motion of the car. [1] - Calculate the minimum coefficient of static friction between the tyres of the car and the road for the car to safely complete its motion around the roundabout. [3] - State and explain any change in your answer to part (b) if: - The mass of the car increases. [2] - The road is banked at an angle so that the car is tilted towards the center of the roundabout. [2] - The speed of the car increases. [2]
markScheme:
- Frictional force (between the road and the car tyres) $\checkmark$
  Weight is not accepted as a response here.
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
It is the force of friction between the road and the tires that provides the force towards the centre of the roundabout. Without friction, the car would not be able to make the turn.
  
- The speed of the car is ($35\textrm{ km h}^{-1}$, which is $\dfrac{35000\textrm{ m}}{3600\textrm{ s}})=$ 9.72 m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
  Frictional force provides the centripetal force, therefore $\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=mg\mu$
  Rearranging gives $\mu=\dfrac{v^2}{rg}$ $\checkmark$
  OR
  The substitution: $\mu=\dfrac{9.72^2}{(15)(9.8)}$ = 0.64 $\checkmark$
  (2 marks max if speed is not converted to m s$^{-1}$. This gives 8.33)
  
- 
  - No change $\checkmark$
    The mass of the car impacts the calculation of the frictional force and centripetal force equally/cancels in the calculation. $\checkmark$
    
  - Decrease $\checkmark$
    The normal force would contribute to the centripetal force, therefore less frictional force would be sufficient. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
On a banked turn, the normal force will have a component that points towards the centre of the circle. As the centripetal force required is the same as on a non-banked turn, less frictional force is required and therefore a lower coefficient of friction is sufficient.
    
  - Increase $\checkmark$
    At a higher speed, a larger centripetal force would be necessary to maintain the circular motion. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
A higher speed will increase the value of $\dfrac{mv^2}{r}$, resulting in the need for a higher value for the coefficient of friction $\mu$.

title: Question 71
content: A box half filled with sand is pulled by a motor at a constant speed of $2.0$ m s$^{-1}$ on a frictionless surface. During the motion, sand is added to the box from above at a constant rate of $\sigma$ kg s$^{-1}$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e91a12f8-310f-42b8-a135-30c0ad0e892e/images/fb1ec50a-d277-4d69-95d5-266cdd06f303/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%201.45.240%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG) - State the condition related to the mass of an object in order for the equation $F_{net}=ma$ to be equivalent to the equation $F_{net}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{t}$ . [1] - The force applied by the motor on the box is $0.11$ N. Determine $\sigma$. [2] - The motor has an efficiency of 75%. Calculate the total power provided to the motor. [2]
markScheme:
- Mass of the object should be constant $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Net force is equal to the rate of change of momentum
  
  
  - $F_{net}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{\Delta (mv)}{\Delta t}$

  Therefore $F_{net}$ can depend on the rate of change of mass or the rate of change of velocity or both.
  The equation
  
  
  - $F=ma$

  is equivalent to
  
  
  - $F=m\dfrac{\Delta v}{t}$

  and therefore assumes that mass is constant and that only velocity is changing with time.
  
- 
  
  - $F=\dfrac{\Delta p}{t}=\dfrac{\Delta(mv)}{t}$
  - $\dfrac{F}{v}=\dfrac{\Delta m}{t}$
  - $\dfrac{F}{v}=\sigma$ $\checkmark$
  - $\sigma=\dfrac{0.11}{2.0}= $ $0.055\textrm{ kg s}^{-1}$  $\checkmark$

  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The force $F$ applied to the box;
  
  
  - $F=\dfrac{\Delta p}{t}=\dfrac{\Delta(mv)}{t}$

  Since $v$ is constant;
  
  
  - $F=\dfrac{v\Delta m}{t}$

  When $\dfrac{\Delta m}{t}$ is replaced with $\sigma$;
  
  
  - $F=v\sigma$
  - $\dfrac{F}{v}=\sigma$ where $F=0.11$ N and $v=2.0$ m s$^{-1}$

  
  
  - $\sigma=\dfrac{0.11}{2.0}=0.055$ kg s$^{-1}$




- Useful power output of the motor $=\ll Fv=(0.11)(2.0)=\gg 0.22$ W $\checkmark$
  The power provided to the motor $=\ll \dfrac{0.22}{75\%} \times 100\% = \gg $  0.29 W $ \checkmark$
  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The useful power output $P_o$ of the motor;
  
  
  - $P_o=Fv=(0.11)(2.0)=0.22$ W

  The efficiency of the motor;
  
  
  - Efficiency = $\dfrac{\textrm{Useful power output}}{\textrm{Input power}} \times 100\%$

  So the input power;
  
  
  - Input power = $\dfrac{\textrm{Useful power output}}{\textrm{Efficiency}} \times 100\%$

  Substitute the given and calculated values;
  
  
  - Input power = $\dfrac{0.22}{75\%} \times 100\% = 0.29\,W$

title: Question 72
content:
Two bodies of masses 2 kg and 3 kg are connected by a thread and pulled in the upward direction with an acceleration of $g$ due to an upward force $F$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/eb9106b9-d99e-4523-b2e9-efa16a2c17a6/images/cbe0daf4-7e77-4429-a129-869ae3fb9bb1/PH0245q.JPEG)


The thread between the masses is cut. Which of the following is correct for the bodies just after the cut?

Acceleration of 3 kg massAcceleration of 2 kg mass$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $g$ $g$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $4g$ $g$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $4g$ $4g$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $g$ $4g$
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:


- $F = ma$

Before the thread is cut,


- $F - W = ma$  for the system
- $W = mg = 5g    $ and  $\ ma=5g$

Therefore


- $F = 5g + 5g = 10g$

Just after the cut, the 3 kg mass is only under the influence of gravity, so its accleration is equal to $g$
The net force on the 2 kg mass is


- $F - 2g = 10g - 2g= 8g $

Acceleration of the 3 kg mass = $g$
Acceleration of 2 kg mass = $ \dfrac{8g}{2} = 4g$

title: Question 73
content:
An object of mass $m$ and initial velocity $v$ collides with a stationary object of mass $2m$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f1971e54-30eb-442a-aa50-607973aad940/images/3fb732f1-87a9-449f-b833-c4c911243712/Screenshot%202025-03-25%20at%207.24.54%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


After the collision the object of mass $2m$ moves with velocity $\dfrac{2v}{3}$.  What is the final velocity of the object of mass $m$ and the magnitude of impulse of the collision?

$\textrm{Final velocity of mass}$ $m$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\textrm{Impulse}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{-v}{3}$ $\dfrac{2mv}{3}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{-v}{3}$ $\dfrac{4mv}{3}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{v}{3}$ $\dfrac{2mv}{3}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{v}{3}$ $\dfrac{4mv}{3}$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Using conservation of momentum, we set the initial momentum equal of the system equal to the final momentum. We can represent the final velocity of the object of mass $m$ as $v_{fm}$. Applying the law of conservation of momentum gives


- $mv=mv_{fm}+2m\left(\dfrac{2v}{3}\right)$
- $v=v_{fm}+2\left(\dfrac{2v}{3}\right)$
- $v_{fm}=v-\dfrac{4v}{3}=\dfrac{-v}{3}$

The negative sign represents the fact that the smaller mass will bounce backwards in the collision.
Impulse $J$ is equal to change in momentum.


- $J=m\Delta v$

The simplest way to find the impulse of this collision is to consider the change in momentum of the ball that is initially stationary.


- $J=m\Delta v=2m\left(\dfrac{2v}{3}-0\right)=\dfrac{4mv}{3}$

title: Question 75
content:
A spherical object of radius $r$ is released from rest inside a fluid, after some time it reaches a terminal velocity $v$. The density of the fluid is $\rho_f$ and the density of the object is negligible compared to $\rho_f$. Which of the following is a correct expression for the viscosity of the fluid?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{2\rho_fr^2g}{9v}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{4\rho_fr^3g}{9v}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{2\rho_fr^2gv}{9}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $\dfrac{4\rho_fr^3gv}{9}$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Because of the very low density of the object, in this situation it will be rising upwards through the fluid and the drag force will be directed downwards. The forces acting on the object are represented in the diagram below:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/fd1b8088-49d6-4cf0-a32e-2f667b767317/images/54c6d222-8e3b-49ea-a0d9-c1152711872e/Screenshot%202025-06-04%20at%209.35.15%E2%80%AFAM.png)


Weight is negligible due to the negligible object density.


- $\rho_{\textrm{object}}\ll\rho_f$
- $(\textrm{weight}=\rho_{\textrm{object}}Vg\ll\rho_{\textrm{object}}Vg=\textrm{buoyancy})$

When the object is at terminal velocity the net force acting on it is zero so we have:


- $\textrm{weight}=\textrm{drag force}$

Where:


- Buoyancy $=\rho_fVg$
- Drag $=6\pi\eta rv$

Where $g$ is acceleration due to gravity, $V$ is the volume of the ball, and $\eta$ is the viscosity of the liquid.


- $\rho_fVg=6\pi\eta rv$

Now substituting the volume of a sphere $V=\dfrac{4}{3}\pi r^3$ and rearranging for $\eta$ we have:


- $\rho_f\dfrac{4}{3}r^3g=6\pi\eta rv$
- $\rho_f\dfrac{4}{3}r^2g=6\eta v$
- $\eta=\dfrac{2\rho_fr^2g}{9v}$

title: Question 76
content:
A stationary object explodes and splits into two parts of masses $m$ and $2m$. Mass $m$ moves north with a velocity of $2v$ and mass $2m$ moves south with a velocity of $v$. Calculate the total change in linear momentum of the system as a result of the explosion.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ff2acbba-2403-4a67-b180-9dbd6ab500fe/images/84602be2-5f8f-4366-be5d-8b3dd6c7f170/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.56.30%E2%80%AFPM.png)




- A. $\hspace{1em}$ Zero
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $1.5mv$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $4mv$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $6mv$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The change in the momentum of the system in the explosion is zero, as the system is isolated and therefore momentum is conserved.

title: Question 81
content: Two blocks of masses 3.0 kg and 4.0 kg are held stationary with a thread connecting the blocks. The mass of 3.0 kg is on a rough incline that makes an angle of 30° with the ground and it starts to slip up when the other mass is slightly more than 4.0 kg. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3e083eeb-2ac3-45c1-a54c-95d8955270d7/images/b43aec29-c2a0-4524-b402-66e35e1e23b1/PH0559MS.png) - State two differences between static friction and dynamic friction [2] - Calculate the coefficient of static friction between the mass of 3.0 kg and the rough surface. [3] - The thread connecting masses breaks and the mass of 3.0 kg slides down. Show that the acceleration of the mass of 3.0 kg is around 1.5 m s$^{-2}$. The coefficient of dynamic friction between 3.0 kg mass and the rough surface is 0.40. [2] - Determine the speed of the mass of 3.0 kg after it has moved through a vertical height of 1.0 m. [2]
markScheme:
- Static friction occurs when the object is not moving (relative to a surface) and Dynamic friction occurs when there is relative motion between the object and a surface $\checkmark$
  The magnitude of static friction is dependent on external forces and the magnitude of dynamic friction is not dependent on external forces OR static friction force can vary up to a maximum while dynamic friction is a constant value  $\checkmark$



- Component of weight parallel to the incline = $\ll mg\sin(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=\gg 15 \ll\textrm{N}\gg$ and tension in thread $T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39$ N $\checkmark$
  Static friction = $\ll 39-15=\gg 24 \ll\textrm{N}\gg$ $\checkmark$
  coefficient of static friction = $\ll \dfrac{24}{(3.0)(9.81)\cos(30°)}= \gg$ 0.96 $\checkmark$ (0.94 to 0.96 accepted)
  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
According to the diagram, the mass of 3 kg is balanced with weight $W$, tension $T$ static friction $F_f$ and normal force $N$;
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3e083eeb-2ac3-45c1-a54c-95d8955270d7/images/e14de16f-c457-499c-989c-258323ec83e0/PH0559Q.png)


  Weight has two components parallel to the incline $W_h$ and perpendicular to the incline $W_v$;
  
  
  - $W_h=mg\sin(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=15$ N down to the slope

  The tension balances the weight of the mass of 4.0 kg;
  
  
  - $T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39$ N

  The forces parallel to the incline must cancel each other;
  
  
  - $\begin{aligned}
     W_h+F_f&=T\\
     \hspace{1em}\\
     15+F_f&=39\\
     \hspace{1em}\\
     F_f&=24\textrm{ N}\\
     \end{aligned}$

  By using the equation of static friction;
  $\begin{aligned}
   F_f&=\mu R\\
   \hspace{1em}\\
   \mu(3.0)(9.81)\cos(30°)&=24\\
   \hspace{1em}\\
   \mu&=0.96\\
   \end{aligned}$
  
- The dynamic friction = $\ll\mu R=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)\cos30°=\gg 10 \ll N\gg$ $\checkmark$
  
  
  - $a$ = $\ll\dfrac{14.7-10.2}{3}=\gg $     1.5 m s$^{-2}$ $\checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
There are only two forces that act on the mass parallel to the incline. They are components of the weight $W_h$ down to the slope and dynamic friction $F_f$ up the slope. The dynamic friction;
  
  
  - $F_f=\mu R=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)\cos(30°)=10$ N
  - $F_{net}=ma$
  - $14.7-10.2=3.0a$
  - $a=1.5$ m s$^{-2}$

  
- displacement of the mass = $\ll \dfrac{1.0}{\sin(30^o)} = \gg 2.0 \ll\textrm{m}\gg$ $\checkmark$
  
  
  - $v = \ll\sqrt{(2)(1.5)(2.0)}=\gg 2.4 \ll\textrm{m s}^{-1}\gg$ $\checkmark$

  OR
  Heat lost due to friction = $\ll F_f d=(10)(2.0)=\gg 20\ll\textrm{J}\gg$ $\checkmark$
  
  
  - $v$ = $\ll \sqrt{\dfrac{(2)(9.0)}{(3.0)}}=\gg$     2.4 m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$

  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The overall displacement s of the mass when it displaced 1.0 m vertically;
  
  
  - $s=\dfrac{1.0}{\sin(30^o)}=2.0$ m

  By using a suvat equation;
  
  
  - $v^2=u^2+2as$ while $u=0$, $a=1.5$ m s$^{-2}$, and $s=2.0$ m
  - $v^2=(2)(1.5)(2.0)=6.0$
  - $v=2.4$ m s$^{-1}$

  This question can be also done with the conservation of energy approach;
  The energy dissipated due to friction is
  
  
  - $Q=F_f d=(10)(2)=20$ J

  and the change in gravitational potential energy can be found by
  
  
  - $\Delta E_p=mg\Delta h=(3.0)(9.81)(1.0)=29$ J

  The gravitational potential energy was converted to thermal energy from friction and kinetic energy, therefore
  
  
  - $29=\Delta E_k+20$
  - $\Delta E_k=9.0$ J

  Solving for speed gives
  
  
  - $\Delta E_k=\frac{1}{2} mv^2$
  - $v=\sqrt{\dfrac{2\Delta E_k}{m}}$
  - $v=\sqrt{\dfrac{(2)(9.0)}{(3.0)}}=2.4$ m s$^{-1}$

title: Question 87
content:
A ball is falling vertically in a liquid. The overall density of the ball and the density of the liquid are the same. Which of the following is correct for the change in speed of the ball and and the direction of the acceleration?

$\hspace{1.5em}$The motion of the ball$\hspace{1.5em}$Acceleration$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$Speeding upUpwards$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$Slowing downUpwards$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$Speeding upDownwards$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$Slowing down$\hspace{1.5em}$ Downwards $\hspace{1.5em}$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Three forces are acting on the ball the weight of the ball, buoyancy, and drag. While buoyancy and drag are upwards, weight is downwards.
The buoyancy :


- $F_B = {\rho}_{liquid}Vg$

Weight:


- $W=mg={\rho}_{ball}Vg$

Since the density of the ball and the liquid are the same, weight and buoyancy cancel each other and the net force acting on the ball is the drag force. Due to having upward net force while moving downwards, the ball must be slowing down. Moreover, if the initial speed was zero at the time of contact with the water, the ball would experience zero net force. The drag force provides a net upwards force, so the acceleration of the ball is upwards.

title: Question 90
content:
A ball of mass $m$ strikes a vertical wall with a speed of $v$. It bounces back with the same speed. The angle between the wall and the trajectory of the incoming ball is $\theta_1$. The angle between the wall and the trajectory of the ball after the bounce is  $\theta_2$. During the collision, the only force that acts on the ball is normal to the wall.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/ad019d36-8753-4d72-a8aa-514000db4270/images/15fb46e9-c502-4194-ac44-81c73f291932/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.42.17%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


What is the magnitude of the change in momentum of the ball?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	2mv(\cos\,\theta_1)$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	2mv(\sin\,\theta_1)$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	2mv(\sin(\theta_1+\theta_2))$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	2mv(\cos(\theta_1+\theta_2))$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The question states that the only force from the wall on the ball during the collision is perpendicular to the surface. Due to the absence of a vertical force, there will be no change in the vertical component of the momentum of the ball, and all of the momentum change is in the horizontal direction.
