Because the collision is elastic, the speed of the ball is unchanged in the collision. As the vertical component of the velocity is unchanged, it follows that the magnitude of the horizontal component of the velocity is also unchanged.
Given that the magnitudes of the components are both unchanged, the angles $\theta_1\ $and $\theta_2$ must be equal.
It has been determined that the only change in momentum is in the horizontal direction.
Therefore,


- $∆p_h=p_{fh}-p_{ih}$
- $p_{ih}=mv\,(\sin\,\theta_1)$

and


- $p_{fh}=-mv(\sin\,\theta_2)$
- $\Delta p_h=p_{fh}-p_{ih}=-mv\sin\,θ_2-mv\sin\,θ_1$

But


- $\theta_1=\theta_2$

Therefore


- $\Delta p_h=-2mv(\sin\,θ_1)$

Thus


- $\Delta p=-2mv(\sin\,θ_1)$

title: Question 95
content:
A mass moving with a constant speed $u$ encounters a rough surface and comes to a stop. The mass takes a time $t$ to stop after encountering the rough surface.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b39534bd-d7cb-4a8d-b23e-28aa458816db/images/37cb5cf0-1f11-43ce-af51-ed8a25184738/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.43.46%E2%80%AFPM.png)


The coefficient of dynamic friction between the rough surface and the mass is 0.40. Which of the following expressions gives the initial speed $u$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	0.2gt$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	0.4gt$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	gt$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	2.5gt$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
When the mass is moving on the rough surface, the only horizontal force acting on it is dynamic friction. Due to Newton’s Second Law, the following relationship can be written:


- $F_f = ma$

using $F_f=\mu_dF_N$ and $a=\dfrac{v-u}{t}$;


- $
  \mu_dF_N=m\dfrac{v-u}{t}$

$F_N=mg$,  therefore


- $\mu_dmg=m\dfrac{v-u}{t}$
- $\mu_dg=\dfrac{v-u}{t}$
- $\mu_dgt=v-u$
- $u=v-\mu_dgt$

By substituting the given values


- $u=0-0.4gt$
- $u=-0.4gt$

Because we are asked for the speed, we can remove the negative sign to get


- $u=0.4gt$

title: Question 96
content:
Three identical masses are connected as shown with a string that passes over an ideal pulley. The tension in the string connecting $m_1$ and $m_2$ is $T_1$. The tension of the string attached to $m_3$ is $T_2$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/39d40768-7d77-4ea9-8484-933e7732fbe0/images/a0a1b313-a16d-4619-920a-428e20554518/PH0546.png)


Which of the following is correct for $T_2$ and the acceleration of  $m_1$?

$\hspace{1.5em} \bf{T_2} \hspace{1.5em}$Acceleration of $\bf{m_1}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $2T_1$ $\dfrac{g}{3}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $2T_1$ $\dfrac{g}{2}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{3T_1}{2}$ $\dfrac{g}{3}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\dfrac{3T_1}{2}$ $\dfrac{g}{2}$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Let all masses be equal to $m$.
For the acceleration, we can assume all masses to be one system. There is a force of gravity of $2mg$ pulling the system one direction, and a force of gravity of $mg$ pulling the other direction.


- $F_{net}=2mg-mg=mg$

The total mass of the system is $3m$.
Therefore the acceleration of the system is the total mass of the system divided by the net force.


- $a=\dfrac{F_{net}}{m}=\dfrac{mg}{3m}=\dfrac{g}{3}$

When Newton's second law is applied to $m_1$;
$\begin{aligned}
ma&=F_{net}\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
m \left( \dfrac{g}{3} \right) &=mg-T_1\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
T_1&=\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)mg\\
\end{aligned}$
When Newton's second law is applied to $m_3$
$\begin{aligned}
T_2-mg&=m\left(\frac{g}{3}\right)\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
T_2&=\left(\frac{4}{3}\right)mg\\
\end{aligned}$
Therefore
$\hspace{2cm} T_2=2T_1$

title: Question 99
content: - Define Newton's First Law. [2] - A block of mass 2.0 kg slides at the constant speed of $v$ on a rough inclined plane. A string attached to the hanging mass of 0.50 kg passes over a pulley and supports the block. The slope of the incline is 25$\degree$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b024c43e-7f2c-4b87-87b1-1c5ac07573a3/images/67a19126-12d9-4478-afd2-f45c35ba5e95/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2011.46.01%E2%80%AFAM.png) $\small{\textrm{[Source: Created with Chemix - https://chemix.org/]}}$ - Show that the direction of the motion of the box is down the slope. [3] - Draw and label a free-body diagram for the forces acting on the block. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b024c43e-7f2c-4b87-87b1-1c5ac07573a3/images/d218363b-c52d-447a-a681-c5888a85a386/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2011.48.51%E2%80%AFAM.png) - Determine the coefficient of dynamic friction between the block and the inclined plane. [3] - In reality, air resistance will also have an effect on the motion of the block and the calculated coefficient of friction. If air resistance were taken into account for this constant speed scenario, discuss how the calculated value would be affected. [2]
markScheme:
- When the net force acting on the body is zero $\checkmark$
  The body has constant velocity/does not accelerate $\checkmark$
  $\textbf{OR}$
  An object at constant velocity $\ll$and in a state of rest$\gg$ will remain so $\checkmark$
  Unless acted on by an external/unbalanced force $\checkmark$



- 
  - Tension/Weight of the mass hunger = $\ll (0.50)(9.81) = \gg$ $4.9$ N $\checkmark$
    The component of the weight of the block on the plane of incline = $\ll (2.0)(9.81)(sin25) = \gg(2.0)(9.81)(0.42)$ = $8.3$ N $\checkmark$
    8.3 > 4.9 $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The direction of the friction on the block should be in the opposite direction of the block's motion.
    There is no acceleration. According to Newton's second law, there is no net force either on the object separately or the system. The forces on the block must be balanced.
    Weight $W_T$ of the block:
    
    
    - $W_T = mg = (2.0)(9.81) = 20$ N

    The component of the weight of the block $W_{Tx}$ on the plane of the incline:
    
    
    - $W_{Tx} = mg\sin25\degree = (19.62)(0.42) = 8.3$ N

    Weight $W_M$ of the mass hanger:
    
    
    - $W_M = mg = (0.50)(9.81) = 4.9$ N

    The weight of the mass hanger should be the tension of the string and the tension of the spring is less than the component of the weight of the block. Therefore, the friction force acting on the block should be up to the slope. The block moves down to the slope.
    
  - $\textrm{ }$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b024c43e-7f2c-4b87-87b1-1c5ac07573a3/images/13bfe0ba-398f-410a-8572-e2e8f45b8c5e/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%2011.54.23%E2%80%AFAM.png)


    Correct directions and labels $\checkmark$
    Weight is longer than the other three by eye $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Four forces are acting on the block. They are weight towards the bottom of the page, normal force perpendicular to the plane of incline, tension and frictional force up to the slope. Since weight balances the vertical components of the other three forces, it should be greater in magnitude. This can be represented by longer arrows in the free-body diagram.
    
  - Normal reaction force = $\ll$ Component of the weight perpendicular to the plane of incline $=\gg 18$ N $\checkmark$
    
    
    - $8.3\textrm{ N} - 4.9\textrm{ N} = 3.4\textrm{ N}$ $\checkmark$
    - $\mu_d = \dfrac{3.4}{18}$ = 0.19 $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The net force acting on the block should be zero. The forces on the plane of incline are the force of dynamic friction, the tension up to the slope and the component of weight down to the slope. The force of dynamic friction $F_f$:
    
    
    - $F_f = \mu_dF_N$

    The component of the weight of the block $W_{Tx}$ on the plane of the incline:
    
    
    - $W_{Tx} = mg\sin25° = (2.0)(9.81)(0.42) = 8.3$ N

    The tension $T$:
    
    
    - $T = W_m = mg = (0.50)(9.81) = 4.9$ N

    The forces that are perpendicular to the plane of the incline are normal reaction force and the component of the weight of the block.
    The component of the weight of the block $W_{Ty}$ perpendicular to the plane of the incline:
    
    
    - $W_{Ty} = mg\cos25° = (2.0)(9.81)(0.91) = 18$ N

    $W_{Ty}$ must be equal to $R$.
    So, dynamic friction can be rewritten as:
    
    
    - $F_f = \mu_dW_{Ty}$

    Since $W_{Tx}$ must be balanced with $F_f$ and $T$:
    
    
    - $F_f+T=W_{Tx}$
    - $\mu_d W_{Ty}=W_{Tx}-T$
    - $\mu_d = \dfrac{W_{Tx}-T}{W_{Ty}} = \dfrac{8.3-4.9}{18} = 0.19$

    
  - air resistance also contributes a force up the slope, which means there is less force due to dynamic friction. $\checkmark$
    the calculated value for the coefficient of friction would be lower $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The direction of air resistance is always opposite to the motion of the object. Therefore, it is in the same direction as the force of dynamic friction and tension. Instead of the force of dynamic friction with tension only, the resultant force of air friction, tension and the force of dynamic friction balances the component of weight. Hence, the force of dynamic friction would be lower. This would lead to a lower calculated value for coefficient of friction.

title: Question 101
content: A washing machine contains a cylinder that carries clothes and rotates in a circular motion about a horizontal axis as shown in the diagram. Frictional forces act between the clothes and the inner surface of the cylinder. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e35b42a3-c332-42ad-854b-e89d4b5c91ff/images/7a7a1a0e-4360-43f7-bff1-e494115729c8/PH0641.png) The radius of the cylinder is $0.27$ m and its linear speed of rotation of the outside of the cylinder is $1.60$ m s$^{-1}$. - Draw the free body diagram for the piece of clothing at the position shown. [3] - - The laundry machine cylinder is designed to make the piece of clothing lose contact with the cylinder at an angle $\theta$ above the horizontal as shown. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e35b42a3-c332-42ad-854b-e89d4b5c91ff/images/a3196421-cf22-4499-a5ba-d1c29429d5da/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.12.44%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG) The free body diagram for the piece of clothing at this position is given below. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e35b42a3-c332-42ad-854b-e89d4b5c91ff/images/b1c0dad4-0f88-4747-b2da-170b6286eea4/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.13.51%E2%80%AFAM.png) Give an expression for the centripetal force at the position shown. [1] - Calculate the angular speed, expressing your answer to the correct number of significant figures. [3] - Show that $\theta=75\degree$ when the piece of clothing loses contact with the cylinder. [2] - Determine the time taken for a piece of clothing to move from the lowest point of the cylinder (point A) to the point where it loses contact. [3] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e35b42a3-c332-42ad-854b-e89d4b5c91ff/images/e607d6fc-b5eb-4a30-8f11-d0eb837b7b2b/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.14.34%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)
markScheme:
- $\hspace{1em}$
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e35b42a3-c332-42ad-854b-e89d4b5c91ff/images/b10324d1-96ec-4217-a8aa-81a044ec36b4/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.11.09%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG)


  Gravitational force vertically downwards. $\checkmark$
Friction force vertically upwards. $\checkmark$
Normal force horizontally to the right. $\checkmark$
  
- 
  - 
    
    - $N + mg \sin\theta$ $\checkmark$

    
  - 
    
    - $\omega=\ll\dfrac{v}{r}=\gg\dfrac{1.60}{0.27}$ $\checkmark$
    - $\omega$ = $5.9\ll\ rad\,s^{-1}\gg$ $\checkmark$

    2 significant figures $\checkmark$
    
  - Normal force is zero $\checkmark$
    
    
    - $\dfrac{mv^2}{r}=mg\sin\theta$ $\checkmark$
    - $\sin\theta=\ll\dfrac{v^2}{rg}\ = \gg\dfrac{{(1.6)}^2}{(0.27)(9.81)}$  $\checkmark$
    - $\theta={\ll75}\degree\gg$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
When the piece of clothing loses contact, the normal force of the cylinder on the clothing is zero.
    The centripetal force in this case is only the component of the gravitational force towards the centre of the circular path.
    
    
    - $mg\sin\theta\ =\dfrac{mv^2}{r}$

    Then,
    
    
    - $\sin\ \theta=\dfrac{v^2}{rg}\ =\dfrac{\left(1.6\right)^2}{\left(0.27\right)\left(9.81\right)}\ =0.967$
    - $\theta  ={75}\degree$

    
  - The angular displacement is 2.9 rad $\checkmark$
    
    
    - $t=\ll\dfrac{\theta}{\omega}\gg=\dfrac{2.9}{5.9}$ $\checkmark$
    - $t$ =$0.49\ll$ s $\gg$ $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Angular displacement is 90$\degree$ + 75$\degree$  = 165$\degree$
    In radians, this gives
    
    
    - $\dfrac{\left(165\right)\left(\pi\right)}{180}=2.9$ rad
    - $t=\dfrac{\theta}{\omega}=\dfrac{2.9}{5.9} $
    - $t=0.49$ s

    Allow ECF for use of $\omega$ value from b(ii)

title: Question 107
content: - State Newton's Third Law. [2] - A block of mass 2.0 kg is placed on another block of mass 5.0 kg. The blocks sit on a frictionless surface, but the coefficient of static friction between the blocks is 0.50. The block at the top is pulled with a varying horizontal force $F$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d3918ccc-5576-4eff-a23b-7749484ed10c/images/be6d5caa-15a5-4319-bcbe-83970ed4e5e3/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.12.55%E2%80%AFPM.png) - Calculate the magnitude of the maximum force $F_{max}$ which results in both of the blocks moving together without slipping. [3] - On the graph, sketch how the force of static friction $F_f$ acting on the bottom block varies with the force $F$. [2] (no need to add values on the axis) ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d3918ccc-5576-4eff-a23b-7749484ed10c/images/8cdd5549-4070-486e-8593-4ad4bbed35bd/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.06.47%E2%80%AFPM.png) $F_{max}$ is your answer to (b)(i) and draw your graph up to $F_{max}$ - According to Newton's Third Law, there must be another force paired with the weight of the top block. Describe this force. [2] - On another occasion, the blocks are moved with the help of a force of $12$ N acting on the block at the top. The drag force $D$ on the blocks is given by $D=0.025v^2$ where $v$ is the speed of the blocks. Calculate the top speed of the blocks for this force. [2]
markScheme:
- when two bodies A and B interact, the $\ll$action$\gg$ $\underline{\textrm{force}}$ that A exerts on B is equal and $\checkmark$
  opposite in direction to the $\ll$reaction$\gg$ $\underline{\textrm{force}}$ that B exerts on A $\checkmark$



- 
  - The magnitude of maximum force of friction = $ \mu_s R =  9.8$ N $\checkmark$
    The acceleration of both blocks = $\ll \dfrac{F_{fmax}}{5} = \gg = 1.96 =2.0$ m s$^{-2}$ $\checkmark$
    $ F = ma  = \ll(5+2)(1.96)=13.7=\gg$ 14 N  $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
To have the blocks moving together, the acceleration of each block must be the same. The vertical forces on each block cancel each other. Therefore, only horizontal forces create acceleration. The only horizontal force acting on the block with a mass of 5.0 kg is the force due to static friction between the blocks. The acceleration of 5.0 kg mass can be found by Newton's second law ($F_{net}=ma$):
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d3918ccc-5576-4eff-a23b-7749484ed10c/images/3af533e6-d79a-41ea-8adb-f805fc93cde4/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.16.32%E2%80%AFPM.png)


    The acceleration of 5.0 kg mass can be found by Newton's second law ($F_{net}=ma$):
    
    
    - $F_f = 5a \hspace{2em}$ (first expression)

    Two horizontal forces are acting on the 2.0 kg mass as $F$ and the force of static friction.
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d3918ccc-5576-4eff-a23b-7749484ed10c/images/4c19e1d9-65aa-4a50-a913-d1ad7c2cc1f6/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.16.22%E2%80%AFPM.png)


    The acceleration of 2.0 kg mass can be found by:
    
    
    - $F - F_f = 2.0a \hspace{2em}$ (second expression)

    Since maximum $F$ is investigated, the maximum value of $F_f$ should be employed.
    
    
    - $F_{fmax}=\mu_s R \hspace{1em}$    where $\mu_s=0.5$ and $R=mg=(2.0)(9.81)=20$ N
    - $F_{fmax} = (0.50)(20) = 9.8$ N

    This is the net force acting on the bottom block. We can use this to find the acceleration. When $F_{fmax}$ is substituted to the first expression:
    
    
    - $9.8 = 5.0a$
    - $1.96$ m s$^{-2}=a$

    As both blocks must have the same acceleration, they can be treated as one object of mass $2 + 5  = 7$ kg
    The applied force F is also the net force for the two blocks
    Therefore,
    
    
    - $F_{net} = ma = (7)(1.96) = 13.7 =14$ N


  
  
  - $\textrm{ }$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/d3918ccc-5576-4eff-a23b-7749484ed10c/images/bf06ade7-18bc-4506-ab6a-19bdab0c0710/Screenshot%202025-05-28%20at%201.08.54%E2%80%AFPM.png)


    a straight line $\checkmark$
    passing through the origin $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
When both of the objects are considered as one block. There is no opposing force due to a lack of friction between the surface and bottom block. Hence, the applied force can not be balanced and the acceleration of the blocks will never be zero. The forces acting on the block at the top are the force of static friction $F_f$  (It is the same as the friction force on the block at the bottom) and applied force F. The net force on the top block:
    
    
    - $F - F_f = 2a \hspace{2em} a \neq 0$

    Due to this relationship, when $F$ is increased, $F_f$ is also increased. The maximum value for the force of static friction:
    
    
    - $F_f = \mu N = (0.5)(2.0)(9.81) = 9.8\textrm{ N}$ when the $F_{max}$ is applied.

    Since there is no scaling on the x and y axis, this relation can be expressed with a straight line passing through the origin at any angle.
    
  - The gravitational pull of  mass at the top $\checkmark$
    on the earth $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The paired force should be on the other object and the same type of force. Since weight is the pull of the earth on the mass, paired force should be the pull of the mass on the earth.
    

- $\hspace{2.2em} F = Dv^2$
  
  
  - $12 = 0.025v^{-2} \checkmark$
  - $v = \ll \sqrt{\dfrac{12}{0.025}} = \gg$ 22 m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The acceleration of the blocks must be zero when they are moving at top speed. The resultant force should be zero to have no acceleration. Since two forces acting on the blocks are drag force and 12 N, they must be balanced by each other;
  
  
  - $F = D v^2$
  - $12=(2.5 \times 10^{-2})(v^2)$
  - $\dfrac{12}{0.025} = v^2$
  - $\sqrt{\dfrac{12}{0.025}} = v$
  - $v = 22$ m s$^{-1}$

title: Question 1
content:
Below shows a Sankey diagram for an LED.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/32db4f78-02b8-43c8-82fb-6de54d482356/images/0cc12eab-6d49-485c-82a5-a201da16c116/Screenshot%202025-07-02%20at%202.58.46%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


Which of the following shows the percentage efficiency of the LED and the total power input?

Percentage efficiencyTotal power input$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $40\%$ $4$ W$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $40\%$ $20$ W$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $60\%$ $4$ W$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $60\%$ $20$ W
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Total power unput = total power output = $12\ +\ 8\ =\ 20$ W
For an LED useful energy is visible light energy:
Percentage efficiency = $\dfrac{\textrm{ Useful energy output}}{\textrm{ Total energy input}}\ (100)\ =\ \dfrac{8}{20}\ (100)\ =\ 40\%$

title: Question 6
content:
A box is pulled by a child with a horizontal force of 5 N. The box moves a horizontal distance of 4 m in a time of 2 s. What is the average power delivered by the child to the box?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 2.5 W
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 5.0 W
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 10 W
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 40 W
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Power = $\dfrac{\Delta W}{t}$ and $W = Fs$


- $W = (5\ \ce{ N})(4\ \ce{m}) = 20$ J
- $P=\dfrac{20\textrm{ J}}{2\textrm{ s}} = 10$ W


Alternative:


- $P_{av} = Fv_{av} = F\bigg(\dfrac{\textrm{s}}{\textrm{t}}\bigg) = 5\bigg(\dfrac{4}{2}\bigg) = 10$ W

title: Question 10
content: - State the law of conservation of momentum. [2] - A stationary body explodes into two pieces of mass as $m_1$ and $m_2$ in opposite directions. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/429bf6fe-dca5-47bd-b7e0-b199cab3baa5/images/eb3d1823-146c-4af3-9a6b-1e4afd9aafe7/PH0463.png) Just after the explosion, the ratio of the kinetic energy of $m_1$ to the kinetic energy of $m_2$ is found to be 9. Calculate the ratio of masses $\dfrac{m_1}{m_2}$. [2]
markScheme:
- When the net force on a system is zero / the system is isolated $\checkmark$
  The momentum of the system does not change / the total momentum is constant $\checkmark$



- The magnitude of the momentum of the pieces is equal $\checkmark$
  
  
  - $\ll \dfrac{\frac{p^2}{2m_1}}{\frac{p^2}{2m_2}} = 9 \gg$
  - $\dfrac{m_1}{m_2} = \dfrac{1}{9}\,\checkmark$

  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Since the body is at rest, the total momentum before the explosion is zero. Due to the conservation of momentum, total momentum after the collision must be zero. The two pieces move in the opposite directions. Therefore, the magnitude of momentum they possess must be the same to cancel each other. The ratio of kinetic energies;
  
  
  - $\dfrac{\frac{p^2}{2m_1}}{\frac{p^2}{2m_2}} = 9$
  - $\dfrac{m_2}{m_1} = 9$

  Therefore,
  
  
  - $\dfrac{m_1}{m_2} = \dfrac{1}{9}$

title: Question 17
content:
A box is pulled up a slope inclined at 30° to the horizontal by a force of $F$. The angle between the direction of $F$ and the plane of the incline is also 30°.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/f7c7fada-3e7a-40ef-8afc-46a456e898cb/images/73fc01a0-5e0f-4607-82ff-a8c692a1b23d/PH0571.png)


The box is pulled a distance of d up along the slope. What is the work done by F on the box?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	Fd\cos(30°) $
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	Fd\cos(60°) $
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	Fd\sin(30°) $
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	Fd\cos^2(30°) $
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The component of the force parallel to the slope can be expressed as


- $F_p=F\cos(30°)$

The work done $W$ is the product of the force $F_p$ in the direction of motion and distance $d$.


- $W=F_pd$
- $W=F\cos(30°) d=Fd\cos(30°)$

title: Question 20
content:
A camping stove uses fuel for cooking food in a pot. The fuel has an energy density of $u\,\ce{J m}^{-3}$, and the volume of fuel consumed is $V$ m$^3$. The energy transferred from the fuel to the cooking pot is $E\,$J.
What is the efficiency of the cooking stove?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{EV}{u}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{u}{EV}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{E}{uV}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{uV}{E}$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:


- Energy density = $\dfrac{\textrm{energy provided}}{\textrm{volume}}$

The energy $E_F$ provided by the fuel (total energy in):


- $E_F = \textrm{Energy density}\times\textrm{Volume}$
- $E_F=uV$

The efficiency $\eta$ of the stove:


- $\eta = \dfrac{\textrm{Useful energy out}}{\textrm{Total energy in}}=\dfrac{E}{uV}$

title: Question 22
content:
A car engine has an input power of $P_{in}$ and efficiency of $\eta$.  Which of the following gives the wasted energy from the engine in time of $t$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ P$_{in}$ $\eta$t
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ P$_{in}$ $\dfrac{\eta}{t}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ P$_{in}$t - P$_{in}$ $\eta$t
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ P$_{in}$t - $\dfrac{\eta}{t}$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Useful power output is given by $P_{in}\eta$, so the useful energy is $P_{in}\eta t$.
Input energy is given by $P_{in}t$,
therefore, wasted energy is given by $P_{in} t$ - $P_{in}\eta t$
Therefore the answer is C.
Alternative 2: 
$E_{Waste} = E_T(100\% - \eta) = P_{in}t(1-\eta) = P_{in}t - P_{in}\eta t$

title: Question 28
content: An elastic bungee cord of natural length $20$ m is being tested. A spherical object, originally at rest, is released from a platform. Air resistance and the mass of the cord are insignificant. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/61cee8d4-0539-4c4c-8657-de344244e996/images/08604633-fc44-4b7b-b6e7-ff05446ce89d/PH0644-000.png) - State the principle of conservation of energy. [2] - Describe the energy changes that take place in the spherical object from the time it is released until it comes to rest for the first time. [2] - Show that the speed of the object just before the cord starts to extend is approximately $20$ m s$^{-1}$. [2] - The magnitude of the average $\underline{\textrm{net}}$ force acting on the object between the point where the cord starts to extend and the point where it reaches maximum extension is $360$ N. The time taken during the fall of the object between these points is $0.28$ s. - Show that the mass of the object is approximately $5.0$ kg. [2] - On the graph below, sketch how the the elastic potential energy $E_{H}$ of the spring changes with the vertical displacement $s$ as the cord stretches. There is no need to add values to the axes. [2] ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/61cee8d4-0539-4c4c-8657-de344244e996/images/a3f03b0a-9936-43ec-b0e8-351bd0ef3d31/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.28.03%E2%80%AFAM.JPEG) - The extension of the cord at the point in time when the object has zero acceleration is $11$ m. Determine the spring constant of the cord. [2]
markScheme:
- (in any process) energy is neither created nor destroyed $\checkmark$
  It can only be transformed from one form into another. $\checkmark$
  
- The gravitational potential energy of the object is converted to the kinetic energy of the object. $\checkmark$
  The kinetic and gravitational potential energy of the object are converted into elastic potential energy within the cord. $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
When it is released, its gravitational potential energy is converted to kinetic energy due to the decrease in height above the ground. As soon as the centre of mass of the object has fallen by $20$ m, the cord starts to extend and store elastic potential energy. As it comes to rest, the object's kinetic and gravitational potential energy are converted to the elastic potential energy of the cord.
  
- 
  
  - $mg \Delta h=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2$ $\checkmark$
  - $v=\answer{19.8\ \ce{ m s}^{-1}}$ $\checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The decrease in height of the object is $20$ m. Its decrease in gravitational potential energy equals the increase in kinetic energy.
  
  
  - $mg\Delta h= \dfrac{1}{2}mv^2$
  - $v=\sqrt{2g\Delta h}$
  - $v=\sqrt{(2)(9.81)(20)}$
  - $v=19.8$ m s$^{-1}$

  Alternatively,
  
  
  - $v^2=u^2+2as$
  - $v^2=0^2+2(-9.81)(-20)$
  - $v=19.8$ m s$^{-1}$

  
- 
  - 
    
    - $F_{avg}\Delta t=\Delta p$ $\checkmark$
    - $m = \answer{5.04\ \ce{kg} }\ \checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The object is stationary and has zero momentum when the cord has maximum extension. By using impulse = change in momentum;
    $\begin{aligned}
      F_{avg}\Delta t&=\Delta p\\
      (360)(0.28)&=m(19.8)\\
      100.8&=m(19.8)\\
      m&=\dfrac{100.8}{19.8}\\
      m&=5.09\textrm{ kg}\\
      \end{aligned}$
    
  - $\hspace{2em}$
    ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/61cee8d4-0539-4c4c-8657-de344244e996/images/91a2589c-b619-4d71-90f8-2a7948064acb/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%208.32.17%E2%80%AF0AM.JPEG)


    Parabolic graph with positive gradient. $\checkmark$
    Passes through origin. $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The elastic potential energy stored in the cord is proportional to the square of the extension. Since the force acting on the cord is downwards due to the weight of the object, the vertical displacement of the object s as the cord starts to extend equals the extension x of the cord.
    
    
    - $s^2\propto x^2\propto E_{H}$

    This relationship can be represented by a graph in the shape of
    
    
    - $y=x^2$

    
  - Weight of the object = force of the spring on the object/$W=kx$ $\checkmark$
    
    
    - $k=\dfrac{W}{x} = \dfrac{49}{11}$
    - $k=\answer{4.5\ \ce{ N m}^{-1}}$ $\checkmark$

    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The forces acting on the object are the weight of the object and the force of spring on the object. When the object has no acceleration, these two forces are balanced by each other. The weight of the object;
    
    
    - $W=mg=\left(5.0\right)\left(9.81\right)=49$ N

    By using Hooke's Law:
    
    
    - $F=kx$
    - $k=\dfrac{F}{x}$
    - $k=\dfrac{49}{11}$
    - $k=4.5$ N m$^{-1}$

title: Question 30
content: - Define momentum. [1] - A golf ball of mass 45 g moving with a constant velocity of 2.0 m s$^{-1}$ undergoes a head-on collision with a stationary ball of mass 2.0 kg. The line that joins the centres of the balls is along the direction of the velocity of the golf ball. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8938a3c8-d2bf-44c4-b8c6-8c7e95c8b110/images/a31f1159-d99f-4baa-a497-a3dd8fb09c8a/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.41.16%E2%80%AFPM.png) - Use Newton's Third Law and Second Law to deduce why the change in momentum of the golf ball is equal and opposite to the change in momentum of the stationary ball during the collision. [3] - The variation of force acting on the golf ball $F$ with the time $t$ during the collision is shown in the graph. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/8938a3c8-d2bf-44c4-b8c6-8c7e95c8b110/images/56c450d9-aa69-4205-b5b8-66efcaaa540a/Screenshot%202025-06-30%20at%205.05.14%E2%80%AFPM.png) Show that the magnitude of the change in momentum of the golf ball is approximately 0.09 kg m s$^{-1}$. [2] - Calculate the speed of the golf ball just after the collision. [3] - Discuss whether the collision is elastic or inelastic. [4]
markScheme:
- The product of mass and velocity. $\checkmark$



- 
  - According to Newton's third Law, the force acting on the golf ball equals and is opposite to the force acting on the stationary ball/$F_g=-F_s$ $\checkmark$
    According to Newton's Second Law, the net force equals the rate of change in momentum/$\dfrac{\Delta p_g}{\Delta t}=-\dfrac{\Delta p_s}{\Delta t}$ $\checkmark$
    Since the time of collision is the same for both of the objects, changes in momenta are equal but in opposite directions/ since $\Delta t$ for each ball is equal, $\Delta p_g=-\Delta p_s$ $\checkmark$
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
According to Newton's third law, the force acting on the golf ball $F_g$ equals and is opposite to the force acting on the stationary ball $F_s$ during the collision.
    
    
    - $F_g=-F_s$

    According to Newton's Second Law, the net force equals the rate of change in momentum. Therefore, the rate of change in momentum of the ball $\dfrac{\Delta p_g}{\Delta t}$   equals and is opposite to the rate of change of momentum in the stationary ball $\dfrac{\Delta p_s}{\Delta t}$.
    
    
    - $\dfrac{\Delta p_g}{\Delta t}=-\dfrac{\Delta p_s}{\Delta t}$

    Since the time of collision is the same for both of the objects, changes in momenta are equal but in opposite directions.
    
  - Area under the graph = impulse / change in momentum $\checkmark$
    change in momentum = $\dfrac{1}{2}(2.4)(72 \times 10^{-3}) = \answer{0.086\ \textrm{kg m s}^{-1}}$ $\checkmark$ (extra significant figures must be shown to receive full marks)
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The area under the “Force acting on the object” “Time of acting force” graph equals the impulse and also the change in momentum. Therefore, the area of the triangle $A_t$ should be calculated to get the change in momentum $\Delta p$;
    $\begin{aligned}
     \Delta p &= A_t\\
      &= \dfrac{1}{2}bh\\ 
      &= \dfrac{1}{2}(2.4)(72 \times 10^{-3})\\
      &=0.086\textrm{ kg m s}^{-1}
      \end{aligned}$
    
  - Use of $\Delta p=mv-mu$ $\checkmark$
    $-0.086=(45 \times 10^{-3})v-(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)$ $\checkmark$ (negative sign on change in momentum must be seen)
    $v=\ll \dfrac{4 \times 10^{-3}}{45 \times 10^{-3}}\gg= \answer{0.089\textrm{ m s}^{-1}}$ $\checkmark$
    Note: Use of 0.09 kg m s$^{-1}$ gives a final speed of 0 m s$^{-1}$. This is accepted if full working is shown.
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The force acting on the golf ball during the collision is towards the left. Hence, the change in momentum of the golf ball must be towards the left. When left is chosen as negative and right is chosen as positive for the vectors, the following relationship can be written for change in momentum;
    $\Delta p=mv-mu$ where $\Delta p=-0.086$ kg m s$^{-1}$, $m=45\times10^{-3}$ kg, $u=2.0$ m s$^{-1}$, and $v=$ final velocity after the collision.
    $\begin{aligned}
     -0.086&=(45 \times 10^{-3})v-(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)\\
     \hspace{1em}\\
     (90 \times 10^{-3})-0.086&=(45 \times 10^{-3})v\\
     \hspace{1em}\\
     4 \times 10^{-3}&=(45 \times 10^{-3})v\\
     \hspace{1em}\\
     \frac{4 \times 10^{-3}}{45 \times 10^{-3}}&=v\\
     \hspace{1em}\\
     0.089\textrm{ m s}^{-1}&=v
     \end{aligned}$
    
  - Kinetic energy before the collision = $\dfrac{1}{2}m_g u_g^2=\dfrac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)^2=0.090$ J $\checkmark$
    Change in momentum of larger ball = 0.086 N s
    
    
    - $p = mv$
    - $0.086=2.0v$

    Speed of the stationary ball after the collision $=0.043\,\ce{m s}^{-1}$ $\checkmark$
    Correct calculation of final total kinetic energy according to the result of (b)(iii)
    
    
    - $E_{total}=\dfrac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(0.089)^2+ \dfrac{1}{2}(2.0)(0.043)^2=0.0020$ J
    - $0.0020$ J $\checkmark$

    Kinetic energy after is less so the collision is inelastic. $\checkmark$
    Note: A calculation leading to the kinetic energy after being equal to the kinetic energy before and a statement that the collision is elastic would score only one mark total.
    
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The total kinetic energy of the balls before the collision $E_{tkb}$ equals the kinetic energy of the golf ball before the collision $E_{kgb}$;
    
    
    - $E_{tkb}=E_{kgb}=\dfrac{1}{2} m_g u_g^2=\dfrac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(2.0)^2=0.090$ J

    The speed of the stationary ball after the collision can be found by
    $\Delta p=mv-mu$ where $\Delta p=0.086$ kg m s$^{-1}$, $m=2.0$ kg, $u=0$ m s$^{-1}$
    
    
    - $\begin{aligned}
       \ 0.086 &=2.0v\\
       \ \frac{0.086}{2.0}&= v\\
       \ 0.043\textrm{ m s}^{-1}&=v\\
       \end{aligned}$

    The total kinetic energy of the balls after the collision $E_{tka}$ equals the sum of the kinetic energy of the golf $E_{kga}$ and stationary balls $E_{ksa}$ after the collision;
    
    
    - $\begin{aligned}
       E_{tka}&=E_{kga}+E_{ksa}\\
       &=\frac{1}{2} m_g v_g^2+\frac{1}{2} m_s v_s^2\\
       &=\frac{1}{2}(45 \times 10^{-3})(0.089)^2+\frac{1}{2}(2.0)(0.043)^2\\
       &=0.0020\textrm{ J}
       \end{aligned}$

    $E_{tkb}>E_{tka}$, the kinetic energy of the systems is not conserved. Therefore, collision is inelastic.

title: Question 33
content:
The engine of a car exerts a constant driving force as the car accelerates from rest along a straight horizontal road. Friction and air resistance are negligible. Which of the following graphs shows how the power of the engine $P$ varies with distance traveled by the car $s$?

A.B.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/55b65c2b-1a3d-497c-9cb3-9430459ba7ff/images/63372b4f-5716-4339-8b66-882283cf92b4/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2011.25.18%E2%80%AFAM.png)

$\hspace{1cm}$![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/55b65c2b-1a3d-497c-9cb3-9430459ba7ff/images/96b2c4f9-dac1-41fa-9bd8-be6fefb7b546/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2011.25.23%E2%80%AFAM.png)

$\hspace{1em}$C.D.![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/55b65c2b-1a3d-497c-9cb3-9430459ba7ff/images/5bfae98b-84b2-4180-9db5-f6759bd83290/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2011.25.28%E2%80%AFAM.png)

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/55b65c2b-1a3d-497c-9cb3-9430459ba7ff/images/e66290cc-6d6b-4620-b582-d97535073873/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2011.25.32%E2%80%AFAM.png)
markScheme:
A
$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:


- $P=Fv$

Force is constant so $P\propto v$.
Constant force implies constant acceleration. So, we may use the equations for constant acceleration (suvat).


- $v^2=u^2+2as$

The car starts from rest so


- $v^2=2as$

Given that $a$ is constant we can say


- $v^2 \propto s$
- $v \propto \sqrt{s}$

So as $s$ increases $v$ increases at a decreasing rate.


- $P \propto v \propto \sqrt{s}$

Therefore


- $P \propto \sqrt{s}$

So as $s$ increases $P$ increases at a decreasing rate and the graph will take the shape of a square-root curve.

title: Question 34
content:
An object is thrown vertically upwards on the surface of the moon. The maximum height that the object can reach is $h$. When the object reaches the height of  $\dfrac{h}{3}$ above the surface, what is the ratio

$\hspace{3cm} \dfrac{\textrm{Kinetic\ energy\ of\ the\ object\ at}\ \dfrac{h}{3}\ }{\textrm{Gravitational\ potential\ energy\ of\ the\ object\ at}\ \dfrac{h}{3}\ }$



- A. $\hspace{1em} 1 $
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{2}{3}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{3}{2}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  2$
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Since there is no atmosphere on the moon, energy is not lost to the surroundings due to air resistance. At the highest position of the object, all of the kinetic energy will have been converted to gravitational potential energy $E_t$.
Thus the total energy of the object:


- $E_t=mgh$

where $mg$ is the weight of the object.
The total energy at $\dfrac{h}{3}$ should be the sum of the kinetic $E_{k\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}$ and the gravitational potential energy of the object $E_{p\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}$.


- $E_t=E_{k\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}+E_{p\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}$
- $mgh=E_{k\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}+mg\dfrac{h}{3}$
- $mg\dfrac{2h}{3}=E_{k\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}$

Therefore


- $\dfrac{E_{k\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}}{E_{p\ at\ \frac{h}{3}}}=\dfrac{mg\frac{2h}{3}}{mg\frac{h}{3}}=2$

title: Question 37
content:
A ball with mass $m$ is released from a height of $h$ and undergoes free fall. The ball hits the ground and rebounds vertically. On rebound, the ball reaches a maximum height of $h'$. The time taken for the collision is $T$. During the collision, what are the change in kinetic energy of the ball and the magnitude of the average net force on the ball?

$\hspace{1em}$ Change in kinetic energy $\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{1em}$ Average force $\hspace{1em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg(h-h')$ $\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg(h'-h)$ $\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} - \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg(h'-h)$ $\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $mg(h-h')$ $\dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} - \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Change in kinetic energy  = Loss of mechanical energy = change in potential energy


- = $mgh' - mgh = mg(h'-h)$

We can find the velocity before hitting the ground using conservation of energy


- $\dfrac{1}{2}mu^2=mgh$

giving


- $u = \sqrt{2gh}$

Similarly, velocity after bouncing from the ground


- $v = - \sqrt{2gh'}$

Change in momentum


- $\Delta p = m (v-u)$ = $m (-\sqrt{2gh'} - \sqrt{2gh})$

Force is rate of change of momentum


- $F_{av} = \dfrac{-m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}$

Because the question asks for the magnitude of the average force, we can take the positive value.


- $F_{av} = \dfrac{m(\sqrt{2gh} + \sqrt{2gh'})}{T}$

title: Question 40
content:
A box of mass $2$ kg is pushed with an initial speed of 10 m s$^{-1}$ on a rough horizontal floor. A uniform frictional force of $10$ N acts on the box. What is the distance travelled by the box at the instant when the kinetic energy of the box is halved?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 10 m
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ 5 m
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 2 m
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 1 m
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The loss of kinetic energy is equal to half of the orinal kinetic energy:


- $E_{k(Lost)}= \dfrac{E_{k(initial)}}{2}$

Work done by friction is equal to the loss of kinetic energy.


- $E_{k(Lost)} = W = F_fs$
- $\dfrac{E_{k(initial)}}{2} = F_fs$

By substituting given values in the equation using $E_k=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2$
$\begin{aligned}
\hspace{2em} \bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg) \dfrac{(2)(10^2)}{2}  &= 10\,s\\
\bigg(\dfrac{1}{2}\bigg)(100) &= 10\,s\\
50 &= 10\,s\\
s &= 5 
\end{aligned}$
Therefore, the answer is B.

title: Question 44
content: A box half filled with sand is pulled by a motor at a constant speed of $2.0$ m s$^{-1}$ on a frictionless surface. During the motion, sand is added to the box from above at a constant rate of $\sigma$ kg s$^{-1}$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/e91a12f8-310f-42b8-a135-30c0ad0e892e/images/fb1ec50a-d277-4d69-95d5-266cdd06f303/Screenshot%202025-05-29%20at%201.45.240%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG) - State the condition related to the mass of an object in order for the equation $F_{net}=ma$ to be equivalent to the equation $F_{net}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{t}$ . [1] - The force applied by the motor on the box is $0.11$ N. Determine $\sigma$. [2] - The motor has an efficiency of 75%. Calculate the total power provided to the motor. [2]
markScheme:
- Mass of the object should be constant $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Net force is equal to the rate of change of momentum
  
  
  - $F_{net}=\dfrac{\Delta p}{\Delta t}=\dfrac{\Delta (mv)}{\Delta t}$

  Therefore $F_{net}$ can depend on the rate of change of mass or the rate of change of velocity or both.
  The equation
  
  
  - $F=ma$

  is equivalent to
  
  
  - $F=m\dfrac{\Delta v}{t}$

  and therefore assumes that mass is constant and that only velocity is changing with time.
  
- 
  
  - $F=\dfrac{\Delta p}{t}=\dfrac{\Delta(mv)}{t}$
  - $\dfrac{F}{v}=\dfrac{\Delta m}{t}$
  - $\dfrac{F}{v}=\sigma$ $\checkmark$
  - $\sigma=\dfrac{0.11}{2.0}= $ $0.055\textrm{ kg s}^{-1}$  $\checkmark$

  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The force $F$ applied to the box;
  
  
  - $F=\dfrac{\Delta p}{t}=\dfrac{\Delta(mv)}{t}$

  Since $v$ is constant;
  
  
  - $F=\dfrac{v\Delta m}{t}$

  When $\dfrac{\Delta m}{t}$ is replaced with $\sigma$;
  
  
  - $F=v\sigma$
  - $\dfrac{F}{v}=\sigma$ where $F=0.11$ N and $v=2.0$ m s$^{-1}$

  
  
  - $\sigma=\dfrac{0.11}{2.0}=0.055$ kg s$^{-1}$




- Useful power output of the motor $=\ll Fv=(0.11)(2.0)=\gg 0.22$ W $\checkmark$
  The power provided to the motor $=\ll \dfrac{0.22}{75\%} \times 100\% = \gg $  0.29 W $ \checkmark$
  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The useful power output $P_o$ of the motor;
  
  
  - $P_o=Fv=(0.11)(2.0)=0.22$ W

  The efficiency of the motor;
  
  
  - Efficiency = $\dfrac{\textrm{Useful power output}}{\textrm{Input power}} \times 100\%$

  So the input power;
  
  
  - Input power = $\dfrac{\textrm{Useful power output}}{\textrm{Efficiency}} \times 100\%$

  Substitute the given and calculated values;
  
  
  - Input power = $\dfrac{0.22}{75\%} \times 100\% = 0.29\,W$

title: Question 45
content: A cannonball is fired horizontally from a cannon positioned at the edge of a cliff. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/075709d5-6b82-4c14-84e3-4e295554dd8f/images/a8bab8c2-0aad-4a4d-8b10-7371910c8ac9/PH0562zzz.png) - In the context of Newton's Laws, explain why the cannon recoils to the left when the cannonball is fired. [2] - The initial recoil speed of the cannon is $1.0$ m s$^{-1}$ and its mass is 1200 kg. - After the ball is fired, the cannon rolls to the left and experiences a resistive force of $8.0$ kN as it rolls. Determine the distance covered by the cannon. [2] - The mass of the cannonball is $9.0$ kg. Show that the magnitude of the velocity of the ball after being fired is approximately $133$ m s$^{-1}$. [2] - Calculate the magnitude of the displacement of the cannonball after $5.0$ s. Air resistance can be ignored. [3]
markScheme:
- By Newton's 3rd law, there is a force to the right acting on the cannonball $\checkmark$
  There is an equal and opposite force (to the left) on the cannon $\checkmark$
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
There is a force acting on the cannonball during the firing. According to Newton's third law, there must be an equal and opposite force on the cannon.



- 
  - $a=\dfrac{F}{m}=\dfrac{8000}{1200}=6.7$ m s$^{-2}$
    $s=\dfrac{v^2}{2a}=\dfrac{1}{(2)(6.7)}= $ 0.074 m
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The deceleration a of the cannon is:
    
    
    - $a=\dfrac{F}{m}=\dfrac{8000}{1200}=6.7$ m s$^{-2}$

    The distance s can be calculated using the uniform acceleration equations
    
    
    - $v^2=u^2+2as$

    where
    
    
    - $v=0$
    - $u=1$ m s$^{-1}$
    - $a=-6.7$ m s$^{-2}$
    - $0=1^2+(2)(-6.7)s$
    - $s=\dfrac{1}{(2)(6.7)}=0.074$ m

    
  - Any reference to the conservation of momentum $\checkmark$
    $v_2 = \dfrac{(-m_1)(v_1)}{m_2} = \dfrac{-(1200)(1.0)}{9.0} = \ll$ -133 m s$^{-1} \gg$ $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Due to the conservation of momentum, the total momentum of the objects before the firing should be equal to the total momentum of the objects after the firing.
    The total momentum of the objects before the firing is zero due to the absence of motion. Therefore there total momentum of the objects after firing is also zero
    
    
    - $0=m_1v_1+m_2v_2$

    where
    
    
    - $m_1=1200$ kg
    - $v_1=1$ m s$^{-1}$
    - $m_2=9.0$ kg
    - $v_2=\dfrac{{-m}_1v_1}{m_2}=\dfrac{-(1200)(1.0)}{9.0}=-133$ m s$^{-1}$

    The negative sign represents the direction of the velocity. Therefore it is opposite to the direction of the motion of the cannon.
    
  - Horizontal displacement $=vt=\left(133\right)\left(5.0\right)=666$ m $\checkmark$
    Vertical displacement=$ut+\fdrac{1}{2}at^2=\dfrac{1}{2}\left(9.81\right)\left(5^2\right)=122$ m $\checkmark$
    Displacement of the cannonball$=\sqrt{{666}^2+{122}^2}= $ 677 m  $\checkmark$
    $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
Due to the absence of air resistance, the horizontal velocity of the ball is constant and vertical velocity increases with the acceleration of free fall. The horizontal displacement x of the cannonball
    
    
    - $x=vt$  where $v=133$ m s$^{-1}$ and $t=3.0$ s
    - $x=\left(133\right)\left(5.0\right)=666$ m

    The vertical displacement y of the cannonball
    
    
    - $y=ut+\dfrac{1}{2}at^2$

    where
    
    
    - $u=0$
    - $a=9.81$ m s$^{-1}$
    - $t=5.0\, s$
    - $y=\dfrac{1}{2}\left(9.81\right)\left(5^2\right)=122\, $m

    The magnitude of the displacement s can be found by using Pythagoras's theorem;
    
    
    - $s=\sqrt{x^2+y^2}$
    - $s=\sqrt{{666}^2+{122}^2}=677$ m

title: Question 46
content:
A system that consists of two light identical springs connected in series stores a total elastic potential energy $E_p$ when a load is added to the springs. One of the springs is then removed and the same load is added to the remaining spring.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/33f5116a-a5fd-45d6-9813-47893ca89f34/images/673d5011-a1de-4871-a58f-ca4a34260938/Screenshot%202025-05-14%20at%202.13.46%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Created with Chemix (https://chemix.org)]}}$
In terms of $E_p$, what is the total elastic potential energy stored in the single spring situation?


- A. $\hspace{1em}$ 2$E_p$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $E_p$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ 0.5$E_p$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ 0.25$E_p$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Using Hooke's law,


- $F=k\Delta x$

the elastic potential energy is


- $E_p=\dfrac{1}{2} k\Delta x^2=\dfrac{1}{2} F\Delta x$.

In the two-spring situation, both springs have an extension given by the equation


- $F=k\Delta x$.

When one of the springs is removed, the load remains unchanged and the remaining spring experiences the same extension. Therefore the elastic potential energy stored is also halved.

title: Question 47
content: Two blocks of masses 3.0 kg and 4.0 kg are held stationary with a thread connecting the blocks. The mass of 3.0 kg is on a rough incline that makes an angle of 30° with the ground and it starts to slip up when the other mass is slightly more than 4.0 kg. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3e083eeb-2ac3-45c1-a54c-95d8955270d7/images/b43aec29-c2a0-4524-b402-66e35e1e23b1/PH0559MS.png) - State two differences between static friction and dynamic friction [2] - Calculate the coefficient of static friction between the mass of 3.0 kg and the rough surface. [3] - The thread connecting masses breaks and the mass of 3.0 kg slides down. Show that the acceleration of the mass of 3.0 kg is around 1.5 m s$^{-2}$. The coefficient of dynamic friction between 3.0 kg mass and the rough surface is 0.40. [2] - Determine the speed of the mass of 3.0 kg after it has moved through a vertical height of 1.0 m. [2]
markScheme:
- Static friction occurs when the object is not moving (relative to a surface) and Dynamic friction occurs when there is relative motion between the object and a surface $\checkmark$
  The magnitude of static friction is dependent on external forces and the magnitude of dynamic friction is not dependent on external forces OR static friction force can vary up to a maximum while dynamic friction is a constant value  $\checkmark$



- Component of weight parallel to the incline = $\ll mg\sin(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=\gg 15 \ll\textrm{N}\gg$ and tension in thread $T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39$ N $\checkmark$
  Static friction = $\ll 39-15=\gg 24 \ll\textrm{N}\gg$ $\checkmark$
  coefficient of static friction = $\ll \dfrac{24}{(3.0)(9.81)\cos(30°)}= \gg$ 0.96 $\checkmark$ (0.94 to 0.96 accepted)
  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
According to the diagram, the mass of 3 kg is balanced with weight $W$, tension $T$ static friction $F_f$ and normal force $N$;
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/3e083eeb-2ac3-45c1-a54c-95d8955270d7/images/e14de16f-c457-499c-989c-258323ec83e0/PH0559Q.png)


  Weight has two components parallel to the incline $W_h$ and perpendicular to the incline $W_v$;
  
  
  - $W_h=mg\sin(30°)=(3.0)(9.81)(0.5)=15$ N down to the slope

  The tension balances the weight of the mass of 4.0 kg;
  
  
  - $T=mg=(4.0)(9.81)=39$ N

  The forces parallel to the incline must cancel each other;
  
  
  - $\begin{aligned}
     W_h+F_f&=T\\
     \hspace{1em}\\
     15+F_f&=39\\
     \hspace{1em}\\
     F_f&=24\textrm{ N}\\
     \end{aligned}$

  By using the equation of static friction;
  $\begin{aligned}
   F_f&=\mu R\\
   \hspace{1em}\\
   \mu(3.0)(9.81)\cos(30°)&=24\\
   \hspace{1em}\\
   \mu&=0.96\\
   \end{aligned}$
  
- The dynamic friction = $\ll\mu R=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)\cos30°=\gg 10 \ll N\gg$ $\checkmark$
  
  
  - $a$ = $\ll\dfrac{14.7-10.2}{3}=\gg $     1.5 m s$^{-2}$ $\checkmark$

  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
There are only two forces that act on the mass parallel to the incline. They are components of the weight $W_h$ down to the slope and dynamic friction $F_f$ up the slope. The dynamic friction;
  
  
  - $F_f=\mu R=(0.40)(3.0)(9.81)\cos(30°)=10$ N
  - $F_{net}=ma$
  - $14.7-10.2=3.0a$
  - $a=1.5$ m s$^{-2}$

  
- displacement of the mass = $\ll \dfrac{1.0}{\sin(30^o)} = \gg 2.0 \ll\textrm{m}\gg$ $\checkmark$
  
  
  - $v = \ll\sqrt{(2)(1.5)(2.0)}=\gg 2.4 \ll\textrm{m s}^{-1}\gg$ $\checkmark$

  OR
  Heat lost due to friction = $\ll F_f d=(10)(2.0)=\gg 20\ll\textrm{J}\gg$ $\checkmark$
  
  
  - $v$ = $\ll \sqrt{\dfrac{(2)(9.0)}{(3.0)}}=\gg$     2.4 m s$^{-1}$ $\checkmark$

  
  $\underline{\textrm{Further Explanation}}$: 
The overall displacement s of the mass when it displaced 1.0 m vertically;
  
  
  - $s=\dfrac{1.0}{\sin(30^o)}=2.0$ m

  By using a suvat equation;
  
  
  - $v^2=u^2+2as$ while $u=0$, $a=1.5$ m s$^{-2}$, and $s=2.0$ m
  - $v^2=(2)(1.5)(2.0)=6.0$
  - $v=2.4$ m s$^{-1}$

  This question can be also done with the conservation of energy approach;
  The energy dissipated due to friction is
  
  
  - $Q=F_f d=(10)(2)=20$ J

  and the change in gravitational potential energy can be found by
  
  
  - $\Delta E_p=mg\Delta h=(3.0)(9.81)(1.0)=29$ J

  The gravitational potential energy was converted to thermal energy from friction and kinetic energy, therefore
  
  
  - $29=\Delta E_k+20$
  - $\Delta E_k=9.0$ J

  Solving for speed gives
  
  
  - $\Delta E_k=\frac{1}{2} mv^2$
  - $v=\sqrt{\dfrac{2\Delta E_k}{m}}$
  - $v=\sqrt{\dfrac{(2)(9.0)}{(3.0)}}=2.4$ m s$^{-1}$

title: Question 49
content:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/a07393e2-13b6-4cef-b722-c8894c128a01/images/c42117b3-7ee7-46c1-b4b9-bd159e6e5cb7/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%204.01.21%E2%80%AFPM.png)


A cart of mass $m$ enters a smooth vertical loop the loop of radius $R$ with a horizontal speed $u$ at the bottom of the track, as shown. The cart just manages to stay in contact with the track at the top most point of its path.
Its speed at the bottom of the loop $u$, is given by:



- A. $\hspace{1em}$ $u=\sqrt{5gR}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}$ $u=\sqrt{4gR}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}$ $u=\sqrt{gR}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}$ $u=\sqrt{2gR}$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Conservation of energy:
$E_k + E_p$ at the bottom of the circle = $E_k + E_p$ at the top of the circle.


- (I)$\hspace{0.8em}$ $\dfrac{1}{2}mu^2+0=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2+mg(2R)$
- $\hspace{2.2em}u^2=v^2+4gR$

Centripetal force at the top of the loop comes from the weight of the cart and the normal reaction force from the track which both point downwards, towards the centre of the circle at that point. Because the question states that the car just keeps contact with the the track, we can assume that the normal reaction force is effectively zero.
Writing Newton’s second law at that point gives:
$\begin{aligned}
\hspace{0.7cm} mg+N &=m\bigg(\frac{v^2}{R}\bigg) \\
\hspace{1em}\\
mg+0 &= m\bigg(\frac{v^2}{R}\bigg) \\
\hspace{1em}\\
{v^2}&= gR \\
\end{aligned}$
Substituting this result into (I) gives


- $u^2=gR+4gR$
- $u=\sqrt{5gR}$

title: Question 50
content:
A mass, $m$, is attached to a spring (of negligible mass) of spring constant $k$ on a smooth horizontal surface. The mass is initially pulled a distance, $x$, from its equilibrium position on the surface and released. At the point where the mass has moved a distance $\dfrac{x}{3}$ from its starting point, the speed of the mass is $v$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/b62c54b1-8f15-4ea7-ab55-a6675f1dc82c/images/e7a41f5e-ccae-4876-b0f5-a8c7b6679199/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%205.22.20%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Which expression is equal to $k$?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{9mv^2}{5x^2}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{5x^2}{9mv^2}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{9mv^2}{8x^2}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{8x^2}{9mv^2}$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Since there is no energy loss due to friction or external forces, the mechanical energy of the system remains constant. After the release of the mass, some of the elastic potential energy of the system is transferred to the kinetic energy of the mass. The extension of the spring at the moment the mass covers the distance of $\dfrac{x}{3}$:


- $x-\dfrac{x}{3}=\dfrac{2x}{3}$

The energy elastic potential energy decreased $\Delta E_H$ after release to the point where the mass covers the distance of $\dfrac{x}{3}$:


- $\Delta E_H=\dfrac{1}{2}kx^2-\dfrac{1}{2}k\Bigl(\dfrac{2x}{3}\Bigr)^2=\dfrac{1}{2}k\dfrac{5x^2}{9}$

The energy is transferred to kinetic energy $E_K$:


- $E_K=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2=\dfrac{1}{2}k\dfrac{5x^2}{9}$
- $k=\dfrac{9mv^2}{5x^2}$

title: Question 55
content:
A trapeze artist is swinging from position A to position C as shown in the diagram.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/59fccbf9-fd3e-4471-9a50-940ba5f27060/images/c0aaf0a7-fc7e-4d09-a5db-088c89da3945/PH0634a.png)


$\footnotesize{\textrm{[Source: Image created using Images by OpenClipart-Vectors from Pixabay - https ://pixabay.com]}}$

The combined mass of the artist and the swing is 70 kg, the length of the rope of the swing is $L$ and the tension in the rope at position B is $T$.
Which expression gives the kinetic energy at position B?


- A. $\hspace{1em} \ \dfrac{L\left(T-700\right)}{2}$
- B. $\hspace{1em} \ \dfrac{LT}{2}$
- C. $\hspace{1em} \ LT$
- D. $\hspace{1em} \ \dfrac{L\left(T+700\right)}{2}$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
At position B, at the bottom of the circular path, the net force is
$\hspace{2em}$ $\sum F=T-mg=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}$
Then, the tension of the rope
$\hspace{2em}$ $T=\dfrac{mv^2}{r}+mg$
and
$\hspace{2em}$ $mg=700 \ N$
The kinetic energy at position B
$\hspace{2em}$ $E_k=\dfrac{1}{2}mv^2$
Rearranging the formula giving the tension we can find an expression for $v^2$:
$\hspace{2em}$ $v^2=\dfrac{r\left(T-mg\right)}{m}$
$\hspace{2em}$ $v^2=\dfrac{L\left(T-700\right)}{m}$
Then
$\hspace{2em}$ $E_k=\dfrac{1}{2}m\left(\dfrac{L\left(T-700\right)}{m}\right)=\dfrac{L\left(T-700\right)}{2}$

title: Question 62
content:
An object of mass $1.0$ kg rests on a rough surface. Another object of mass $2.0$ kg is connected to it with a string.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/da1c56d0-cbd4-4733-83bb-5f602f012e48/images/5ad23e85-206e-4711-b2ed-20c0481d45a3/Screenshot%202025-07-08%20at%205.53.49%E2%80%AFPM.png)


When the objects are released, the masses accelerate at $\dfrac{g}{2}$. The work done by the tension of the string on the $1.0$ kg mass is $40$ J. Which of the following is correct for the $1.0$ kg mass during this period?

Magnitude of the force of friction / NDistance travelled / m$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$10$4.0$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$5$4.0$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$10$2.0$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$5$2.0$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The acceleration is given as $\dfrac{g}{2}$ which is equal to $\dfrac{10}{2} = 5$ m s$^{-2}$
The free body diagram of the forces on the mass of $2.0$ kg:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/da1c56d0-cbd4-4733-83bb-5f602f012e48/images/c2d6f4fb-acd4-4d56-a0c4-8def2c43d211/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.18.45%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


According to Newton's second law, the relationship between tension $T$, the weight of the object $W$ and the acceleration of the object:
$\begin{aligned}
F_{net}&=ma\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
W_2-T&=(2.0)(5)\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
(2)(10)-T&=(2.0)(5)\\
\hspace{2.3cm}\\
T&=10\textrm{ N}\\
\end{aligned}$
The free body diagram of the forces on the mass of $1.0$ kg:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/da1c56d0-cbd4-4733-83bb-5f602f012e48/images/60248a9f-84bf-4dfd-b06e-48f3db63eec5/Screenshot%202025-05-30%20at%2012.18.51%E2%80%AFPM.JPEG)


The normal reaction force $F_N$ of the ground on the box balances the weight $W$ of the object. According to Newton's second law, the relationship between Tension $T$, the force of friction on the object $F_f$ and the acceleration of the object


- $T-F_f=(1.0)(5)$

When the magnitude of $T$ is substituted in the equation;


- $10-F_f=(1.0)(5)$
- $\hspace{2em}F_f=5$ N

The work done $W$ by $T$ can be found by the product of $T$ and the distance $d$ travelled by the object.


- $W_1=Td$
- $40=10d$
- $d=4.0$ m

title: Question 64
content:
A mass of $m$ kg is hung on the end of the spring. When the system is in equilibrium, the elastic potential energy stored in the spring is $E$.
A downward force is then applied to the system causing the total elastic potential energy stored to double. This is shown in the diagram below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/994b69a7-9232-4ddf-af1a-8fc88644a46e/images/f5d4dd36-540a-481c-9368-870249a86090/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.50.30%E2%80%AFAM.png)


[© Revision Village 2022. Created with https://chemix.org/]
The downward force is then removed, and the system oscillates about the equilibrium position.
What is the magnitude of the downward force and the kinetic energy of the mass as it passes the equilibrium position?
You may assume friction and air resistance are negligible.

Magnitude of downward forceKinetic energy of mass as it passes equilibrium$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$($\sqrt {2}$ - 1)$mg$ $E$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$($\sqrt {2}$ - 1)$mg$(3 $-$ 2 $\sqrt {2}) E$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\sqrt {2}\,mg$ $E$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$ $\sqrt {2}\,mg$(3 $-$ 2 $\sqrt {2}) E$
markScheme:
B

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Let


- $E = \dfrac {1}{2} kx{^2}$

Where $k$ is the spring constant and $x$ is that extension of the spring when it is in the equilibrium position. (This is the length of the spring with mass $m$ attached - natural length of the spring).
Let $W = mg$ be the (weight) force of the mass hanging on the spring.


- $W = kx$

Substituting $x = \dfrac {W}{k}$ into $E = \dfrac {1}{2} kx{^2}$  gives


- $E = \dfrac {W{^2}}{2k}$

$k$ is constant so we may say that $E$ $\alpha$ $W{^2}$


- $\dfrac {E}{W{^2}}$ = constant

So, we may write


- $\dfrac {W{^2}}{E} = \dfrac{(F_{t})^2}{2E}$

where $F_{t}$ is the total force acting on the spring when it is being pulled down.


- $W{^2} = \dfrac{(F_{t})^2}{2}$



- $2W{^2} = {(F_{t})^2}$



- $\sqrt {2} W = F_{t}$

Finding the extra force gives


- $F_{extra}=F_{t} - W = \sqrt {2} W - W = (\sqrt {2} - 1) W = (\sqrt {2} - 1)mg$

For kinetic energy:
$E_{k}$ is not equal to $2E - E = E$ because $GPE$ is involved as well as $E_{k}$ and $EPE$.
The simplest way to treat this scenario is to consider the ‘extra force’, $F_{extra}$ and ‘extra extension from equilibrium’, $x_{extra}$.


- $F_{extra}$ = $kx_{extra}$

And $k = \dfrac{mg}{x}$
So


- $(\sqrt {2} - 1)mg = \dfrac{mg}{x}(x_{extra})$
- $(\sqrt {2} - 1) = \dfrac{1}{x} (x_{extra})$
- $(x_{extra})= (\sqrt {2} - 1)x$
- $E_{k} = \dfrac{1}{2}k((\sqrt {2} - 1)x){^2}$
- $E_{k} = \dfrac{1}{2}kx{^2}((\sqrt {2} - 1)){^2}$
- $E_{k} = E ((\sqrt {2}){^2} - \sqrt {2} - \sqrt {2} + 1)$
- $E_{k} = (3 - 2 \sqrt {2})E$


$\underline{\textrm{Further intuition}}$:
It may seem strange that $E_{k} = \dfrac{1}{2}k(x_{extra})^2$  because:


- $1)$ $EPE$ $\not= E_{k}$ because $GPE$ is also involved
- $2)$ $A$ $\propto$ $B{^2}$ does not imply that (Extra A) $\propto$ (Extra B)${^2}$
- $\hspace{1em}$For example: If $A = B{^2}$, $1 = 1{^2}$ and $4 = 2{^2}$ but $(4 - 1) \not= (2 - 1){^2}$

But it turns out that these facts taken together produce the result that $E_{k} = \dfrac{1}{2}k(x_{extra})^2$ . Here is proof:
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/994b69a7-9232-4ddf-af1a-8fc88644a46e/images/2ed1869c-46b6-41fc-bb1d-862f99f222a5/Screenshot%202025-06-02%20at%2010.49.31%E2%80%AFAM.png)


If the spring is in position 3 and the extra force is released, the mass will move upwards (past position 2) and oscillate in simple harmonic motion with position 2 as the equilibrium.
Let us take $GPE$ to be zero in position 3.
Total energy in position $3 = \dfrac{1}{2}k(x + y){^2} = \dfrac{1}{2}k(x{^2} + 2xy + y{^2})$
Total energy in position $2 = E_{k} + mgy + \dfrac{1}{2}kx{^2}$
Energy is conserved so $E_{k} + mgy + \dfrac{1}{2}kx{^2} = \dfrac{1}{2}k(x{^2} + 2xy + y{^2})$


- $E_{k} + mgy + \dfrac{1}{2}kx{^2} = \dfrac{1}{2}kx{^2} + kxy+ \dfrac{1}{2}ky{^2}$
- $E_{k} + mgy = kxy + \dfrac{1}{2}ky{^2}$

Now $k = mgx$ so


- $E_{k} + mgy = (\dfrac{mg}{x})xy + \dfrac{1}{2}ky{^2}$
- $E_{k} + mgy = mgy + \dfrac{1}{2}ky{^2}$
- $E_{k} = \dfrac{1}{2}ky{^2}$
- $E_{k} = \dfrac{1}{2}k(x_{extra})^2$

title: Question 12
content:
A uniform beam of total length $L$ and mass $m$ is hinged on one end and acted upon by a horizontal force of magnitude $F$ on its other end.
The beam is held stationary at rest at an angle $\theta$ above the horizontal as shown in the diagram below.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/648289e9-f8b8-498b-a242-e4013c1aede6/images/2a6cb9b3-26cf-446b-82e6-8eaa0049c35a/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%202.37.01%E2%80%AFPM.png)


Which of the following correctly expresses the value of $F$?



- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ $2mg\tan{\theta}$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{2mg}{\tan{\theta}}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{mg}{2\tan{\theta}}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ $\dfrac{mg\tan{\theta}}{2}$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The beam is in rotational equilibrium which means that the total torque (from any point) must be zero.
Taking the axis of the hinge as the centre of torques there are two forces exerting torque on the beam: weight and the horizontal force of magnitude $F$.
The magnitude of the torque exerted by the weight is given by:


- ${\tau}_{weight}=\dfrac{L}{2}mg\cos{\theta}$

The magnitude of the torque exerted by the horizontal force is given by:


- ${\tau}_F=L(\sin{\theta}) F$

By equating these equations, we get:


- $\dfrac{L}{2}mg\cos{\theta} = L(\sin{\theta}) F$

Which can be solved for $F$ leading to:


- $F=\dfrac{mg\cos{\theta}}{2\sin{\theta}}=\dfrac{mg}{2\tan{\theta}}$

title: Question 13
content:
An object which is initially rotating with a frequency of 2 s$^{-1}$. It is acted upon a constant torque which produces an angular deceleration of magnitude 6 rad s$^{-2}$.
Which of the following best describes the number of complete rotations of the object until it comes to rest?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  $ 2
- B. $\hspace{1em}  $ 3
- C. $\hspace{1em}  $ 4
- D. $\hspace{1em}  $ 6
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The angular speed can be expressed in terms of the frequency of rotation $f$ as:


- $\omega=2\pi f$

The object is initially rotating with an angular speed equal to:


- $\omega = 2\pi (2\textrm{ s}^{-1} )$
- $\omega = 4\pi \, \text{rad}\textrm{ s}^{-1}$

Given that the torque is described constant (constant angular acceleration) the following equation from the booklet can be used:


- ${\omega}_f^2={\omega}_i^2+2\alpha \theta$

Substituting the given values and the fact that as the object comes to a rest $ω_f$ is zero, the equation can be written as:


- $0=(4\pi \, \text{rad s}^{-1})^2+2(-6\,\text{rad s}^{-2} )\theta $

Solving for $\theta$ leads to:


- $\theta=\dfrac{(4\pi \, \text{rad s}^{-1})^2}{12\, \text{rad s}^{-2}}=\dfrac{4}{3}{\pi}^2 \, \text{rad}$

This value represents the angle through which the object rotates until coming to a rest. It can then be divided by $2\pi$ leading to the number of complete rotations.


- #rotations $=\dfrac{\theta}{2\pi}=\dfrac{2}{3}\pi$
- #rotations $\approx 2.09$

title: Question 15
content:
A uniform rod of mass $M$ and length $L$ rotates around a vertical axis through its center. Two equal forces act on the rod as shown in the diagram.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/abc8552b-f2af-406e-9782-98ecc856ffa9/images/643b69ac-8b0a-4838-b20d-66e33be9978b/Screenshot%202023-08-07%20at%202.12.35%20PM.png)


The moment of inertia of the rod when rotating about its centre is  $\dfrac{1}{12} ML^2$.
Which of the following gives the angular acceleration of the rod?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  0$
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{6F}{ML}$
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	\dfrac{12F}{ML}$
- D. $\hspace{1em}  \dfrac{24F}{ML}$
markScheme:
C

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
The net torque of the two forces is


- $\tau =2Fr$

Since


- $r=\dfrac{L}{2}$

Then


- $\tau =2F\dfrac{L}{2}=FL$

The torque is related to angular acceleration by


- $\tau =I\alpha$
- $FL=  \dfrac{1}{12} ML^2 \alpha$
- $\alpha=\dfrac{12F}{ML}$

title: Question 13
content:
At a relativistic speed, a rocket journeyed from Earth to Saturn. The duration of the travel is measured according to the stationary observer on earth as $t$. The length of the rocket is measured according to the observer in the rocket as $L$.  Which of the following is correct for the time of travel according to the observer in the rocket and the length of the rocket according to the observer on the Earth?

Time of travel (rocket observer)Length of the rocket (Earth observer)$\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$Less than $t$Shorter than $L$ $\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$Less than $t$Longer than $L$ $\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$Greater than $t$Shorter than $L$ $\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$Greater than $t$Longer than $L$
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
At relativistic speeds, the duration of an event measured by an observer in the same reference frame as the event is shorter than the measured time by the stationary observer due to dime dilation. Therefore, the time of travel should be measured as less than $t$. Similarly, when an object moves at a relativistic speed relative to an observer, its length appears to contract in the direction of motion from the perspective of the stationary observer. Hence, the length of the rocket should be shorter than $L$.

title: Question 22
content:
A spaceship is moving at a speed of $0.80 c$ relative to a stationary observer on Earth. An event occurring in the spaceship is measured by an observer in the spaceship to have a duration of $12$ s. What is the duration of the event as measured by the stationary observer on Earth?


- A. $\hspace{1em}  	7.2$ s
- B. $\hspace{1em}  	12$ s
- C. $\hspace{1em}  	15$ s
- D. $\hspace{1em}  	20$ s
markScheme:
D

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}$:
Lorentz factor for the situation:


- $\gamma=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{v^2}{c^2}}}=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{{(0.8c)}^2}{c^2}}}$
- $\hspace{1em} =\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-0.64}}=\dfrac{1}{0.6}=\dfrac{5}{3}$

Time measured by stationary observer


- $=\gamma t=\left(\dfrac{5}{3}\right)\left(12\right)=20$ s

title: Question 26
content:
A train with a proper length of $500$ m  is moving at a speed $v=0.76c$ with respect to an external stationary observer $X$.
![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/212f2581-bbe3-4530-99ef-33fcb93ee8ae/images/18eafed2-6eca-4fbf-8d4c-5a651623a1e0/Screenshot%202025-06-03%20at%205.14.22%E2%80%AFPM.png)


When exactly half the train has passed next to the observer, two light bulbs placed at opposite ends of the train are turned on simultaneously, according to the frame reference of the train.
According to observer $X$, which light bulb is turned on first and what is the time interval, $\Delta t$ between the two lights turning on?

$\hspace{1.5em}$ Turns on first $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\Delta t$ $\hspace{1.5em}$ $\hspace{1.5em}$A.$\hspace{1.5em}$A$1.95\,\mu$s$\hspace{1.5em}$B.$\hspace{1.5em}$B$1.95\,\mu$s$\hspace{1.5em}$C.$\hspace{1.5em}$A$3.90\,\mu$s$\hspace{1.5em}$D.$\hspace{1.5em}$B$3.90\,\mu$s
markScheme:
A

$\underline{\textrm{Explanation:}}$
There two independent events which correspond to both light bulbs turning on.
The coordinates of these events, according to the reference frame $S'$ (moving train) are as follows:
$t_A'=0;\ x_A'=-250$ m $\hspace{5em}$ $t_B'=0;\ x_B'=250$ m
In order to find the time coordinates of these events in the frame of the observer we can use Lorentz transformation:


- $t=\gamma \Bigl(t'+\dfrac{vx}{c^2}\Bigl)$
- $t_A=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{(0.76c)^2}{c^2}}}\Bigl(0+\dfrac{(0.76 c)(-250\,\ce{m})}{c^2}\Bigr)$
- $\hspace{1.2em}=-9.74\times10^{-7}$ s
- $t_B=\dfrac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{(0.76c)^2}{c^2}}} \Bigl(0+\dfrac{(0.76c)(250\,\ce{m})}{c^2}\Bigr)=9.74\times10^{-7}$ s

These times represent the instants in which the lights are turned on according to the reference frame of the observer. For the observer to see the lights turned on, light would have to travel to the observer. Due to the symmetry of the situation, both signals would have to travel through the same distance up to the observer's eyes, this means that the time difference $t_B-t_A$ is the same as the time difference received by the observer.
It is then:


- $\Delta t=t_B-t_A=1.95\times10^{-6}\,\ce{s}=1.95\,\mu$s
